text:
Wow!  This was really easy and very delicious.I omitted the olive oil because I thought putting both olive oil and butter would be too much.  I also seasoned the chicken a little so that it would not be bland (garlic and onion powder, salt, and pepper).  I also threw in some minced garlic in the butter as the chicken cooked.  If you like mushrooms, I would put 2 cups intead of one.  I served this dish with mashed potatoes and leeks.  Overall, I would definitely make this again.

None
text:
I've made this dish about 4-5 times now and every time, it just gets better!  As with all the other reviews I use more marsala wine (we love sauce, so added 1.5 cups) and I also add 1 cup white wine.  The most important thing is to boil out the alcohol, leaving just the flavor of the wine.   This usually takes about 5-8 minutes.  I also add a dash of cream to thicken up the sauce and give it the taste you would get at a restaurant.  The chicken marsala tastes amazing with angel hair pasta. :)  Enjoy!

text:
I've done this several times and have always enjoyed it BUT - two things need to be clarified.  Marsala comes in both a sweet and a dry.  Which to use?  Normally I use a combination of both. But the second is more important.  DO NOT USE COOKING SHERRY.   This is a cheap American "sherry" with a large dose of salt so that it is very unpleasant to drink.  Just use the Marsala, 3/4 cup.  I also normally reduce both the olive oil and the butter to cook the chicken.  In addition, if not using pre-sliced mushrooms, slice the mushrooms while the breasts get their first cooking.,

text:
Ok I admit...I cheated...I made this even though I didnt have Marsala wine, against the advice of many reviewers...it just sounded too good not to try, and I was tired of finding great recipes only to realize I had about half the ingredients needed :)  The good news is that it was still delicious!  

I used a good Pinot Noir instead (yes I know its nothing like Marsala, but hey its what I was drinking at the time :p) and added a teaspoon of brown sugar after the sauce had reduced as the sauce needed it.  I did use the sherry and cooked most everything else as in the recipe, but with 50% less oil and butter, and adding a smidge of cornstarch/water to thicken the sauce at the end.  Served it with steamed potatoes and garlic asparagus.  Delicious!

It was a hit with the hungry peeps in the family (I've found that if don't feed them very often they just LOVE what I make!) and is going into rotation, I may even be really crazy and buy some Marsala wine next time...but then again maybe the Pinot made it even better!? ;o)

text:
I doubled the marsala and sherry being that I had 8 thinly sliced chicken breasts. After I simmered everything I took out the chicken and set aside the sauce and mushrooms and made a roux with 2 tablespoons of the leftover dredging mix and 4 tbs of butter.  Added the sauce back to the pan with the roux and whisked it all together adding some chicken broth. Added the chicken back to the pan to let it all come together. Made buttered noodles for a side and spooned the sauce over them....OMG DELISH!

This is one of our favorites. My husband loves it and can't wait to get home when he knows we're having it. Since I'm a sauce-aholic I always double the sauce. text:
Very tasty.  I just used 3/4 of a cup of marsala wine, I didn't have any cooking sherry, and it was just the cheap stuff from the grocery store since I don't drink wine.  I used about 2 pounds of chicken, which was 3 very large breasts and I cut them in half and pounded them down to get 6 good sized pieces. I'm not sure if the original recipe was for about a pound of chicken but I thought it didn't make very much sauce.  I added 1/2 a large onion, and sauteed the onion and mushrooms for a bit in the butter and I used garlic flavored olive oil.  Then added the chicken back in and poured the wine on top.  I think I could have easily doubled the sauce recipe, so if you are looking for a lot of sauce, I recommend doing that.  Thickening it with cornstarch or adding a little cream might have been good too.

text:
Super delicious, quick & easy! I tweaked the recipe a bit. Shook pounded chicken breasts in a ziplock freezer bag with the flour, salt, pepper.. Added some paprika, garlic powder, onion powder, Italian seasoning. After browning chicken in the butter/ oil, removed them & set aside. I then sautéed diced onion, red bell pepper& minced garlic with the mushrooms (used double the shrooms) Added 1.5 x the amounts of sherry & Marsala. Then replaced chicken to mix. Simmered low 10 minutes, turning chicken once more. Lastly, thickened the sauce with corn starch/ water combo. Served over rice. Wonderful flavor!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is my go-to recipe for chicken marsala.  Here are my adds:

1.  When I'm in a hurry (always!) I just slice the chicken horizontally across the breast for 1/4 - 3/8ths slices.  You get a lot of uniform slices out of a big breast.
2.  No sherry, increase the marsala.
3.  After removing the chicken from the pan, sautee mushrooms, add a couple tbs of butter and about a tbs of flour for a roux
3.  (For more sauce) I add about 1 - 1 1/2 cups chicken broth (increase the marsala to taste).
4.  Put chicken back in pan, sprinkle with about 1/3 cup chopped parsley.  
5.  Give it a squeeze of 1/4 - 1/2 a lemon.

We like it over spaghetti, sprinkled w/parmesan.  yum.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2169404.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent recipe for chicken in marsala wine sauce.  I did ammend the recipe slightly, according to the recommendations of other reviewers. I pounded and coated the chicken in a Ziploc bag.  I then lightly pan fried the chicken until cooked (omitting the butter and using less EVOO than called for, to cut fat), then removed from pan.  I proceed to brown some sliced onion via the water-method.  Once browned and evaporated, I added the wine and sherry, as well as 1 fresh garlic clove (crushed by a garlic press). I simmered until it started to cook down a bit.  I added (and tripled) the mushrooms and simmered until soft.  I continued to simmer with the objective of reaching a reduction,  but I grew impatient and just added a little slurry (cornstarch and water). Once the sauce thickened, I split the sauce into 2 portions and added a splash of heavy whipping cream to one portion (I recommend using VERY little,  or it will be too rich) and simmered a bit longer. While both delicious, of the two versions I yielded,  I preferred the marsala cream sauce.  Excellent recipe; I will use again and again!

text:
This was great!  I made as-is but eliminated the mushrooms because I wasn't sure my family would eat them.  I also put the flour mixture in a baggie and didn't have enough to coat all of the chicken so I ended up doubling that part of the recipe.  I added the chicken to the oil/butter too soon and my chicken ended up not brown enough and a bit soggy.  Make sure to wait until the oil/butter is hot enough.  I also pounded my chicken too thin and it just crumbled into pieces.  But with all of my personal short-comings, it was fantastic and tasted great!  I did add a bit of flour after I removed the chicken to thicken the sauce.  Next time I will not omit the mushrooms (my family said they missed them!) I will not pound so thin and I will make sure I add the chicken at the right time to the pan.  Even with how it turned out tonight I would put it up against any restaurant version.  Awesome recipe!!!

text:
AWESOME!!! Hubby's top 5 favorite! I did follow some of the suggestions such as adding sliced garlic, chopped onion, and I used all Marsala wine. I also cut the butter and oil in half and it worked just fine! Only other tweak I need to make is increasing that amazing sauce! I served this over mashed potatoes.
Just a note for those looking for Marsala wine (not the cooking kind). I think most grocery stores carry the cooking wine in the oil/vinegar section of the store but this is simply not the same as the drinking Marsala wine. Let me tell you I was about to give up the search for the real stuff but I'm so glad I didn't! As is the case in my state (SC), if you are having a hard time  finding the 'real' Marsala wine then look at places where hard liquor is sold. I was told that this wine has more alcohol than typical wine and the store needs to have a liquor licence. I'm guessing this is accurate based on my search results!!

text:
Oh hot dayyyyyyum we have a new favorite in the house! I followed the recommendations and floured and browned my chicken breast and then kept them warm in the oven at 250 degrees, I just didn't have enough room in my pan. THEN I made the sauce... I doubled/tripled the sauce ingredients for the sauce and added in cornstarch with chicken broth to thicken it. Using REAL Marsala wine is the trick and not the cooking Marsala stuff. Lastly, instead of submerging the chicken back in the sauce I just poured the sauce over it. Served it with the Pasta e Olio (also on this site) with broccoli and it was outstanding!!!! One last note I have on it...depending on the size of your pan and your approach (such as mine) it did NOT take 30 mins to make, more like 60 since we had large chicken breasts that were pounded out and I could only do one breast at a time....just a heads up. May even try this with chicken tenders next time for quick mixing.

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674138.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love this recipe. It's an easy, elegant way to do chicken. I precisely had been  following this recipe. However, I now have made the following tweaks.

1. Brown both sides of the chicken, then remove from pan. (My experience with this recipe indicates that the leaner chicken breasts dry out.)
2. Substitute dried shiitake mushrooms, rehydrated according to package directions. Add the mushrooms to the pan & stir occasionally until browner.
3. Combine the marsala & the sherry. To that mixture, add about 1 teaspoon fresh oregano or 1/2 teaspoon dried. Pour over the mushrooms.
4. Return the chicken to the pan. Simmer for 3 minutes then turn over & simmer for an additional 3 minutes or until juices run clear.
5. Whisk in remaining butter, allowing sauce to thicken. Then season to taste with salt and pepper. 
6. Serve with preferred side dish. (It goes very well with Easy Rice Pilaf.)

My family loved the shiitake mushrooms over the button I had been using because of the stronger flavor imparted to the sauce.

Rather than pound the chicken to a uniform thickness, I slice the chicken through the center of the breast to produce cutlets. I suppose this step is similar to butterflying the breast.

text:
This was very quick, easy, and very tasty!  I would absolutely make it again.  Followed the suggestions of others to double the liquids -- and I might seriously consider tripling them next time I make it.  I cut the olive oil and butter by about a third and didn't miss it.  Added a finely diced half a red onion, a tablespoon of minced garlic (possibly a little too much -- might reduce that in the future), a little bit of thyme and tarragon, and used dry sherry instead of cooking sherry.  Sauce was thicker than traditional marsala but was tremendously flavorful and luscious.  This is definitely a keeper.

text:
I really liked this recipe and it was easy to prepare in advance.  I used cooking Sherry and Marsala Wine which I had in my cupboard.  I doubled the sauce and mushrooms, adding 1/4 cup of stock, 1/4 Half & Half and some cornstarch to thicken.  I used less salt, used Italian Seasoning instead of Oregano (didn't have any).  
I browned the chicken lightly, placed in casserole dish with the sauce and refrigerated for several hours. Cooked in covered dish in oven at 350F for 40 minutes. Then switched oven off until ready to serve - with rice and green beans.

text:
I made this for supper tonight and I thought is was ok. The rest of my family liked it just fine.  I added extra spices to the flour and half and half to the wine sauce. The best part I want to talk about is  pounding the chicken to 1/4".  I had read/heard a hint somewhere to save the waxed paper bag from the empty cereal box to use for cooking.  I thought that was a good way to get bugs in the cabinets here at home.  We emptied a box of cereal this morning so I used it as the pounding container for 6 chicken breast halves.  It worked amazingly well.  I pounded 2 at a time and it held through all 6. The best part was the clean-up.  So easy and not messy at all.  Give it a try - you'll be glad you did.

country:
None
text:
This and a garlic bread recipe are the only recipes I considered reviewing because I love them so much. I enjoy many wine-based dishes, however, so that could contribute to my affinity to this chicken marsala. I always try to follow recipes to the T the first time because I only think it's fair to do so, and the chicken marsala came out splendid! The only thing I changed was the fat content: 3 tbs butter +1 tbs oil. I am very glad I did because it tasted fantastic while being lower in fat, despite the sauce content being less then it otherwise wouldn't have been. So yea, I don't know how anyone could dislike this recipe, and it definitely deserves all the high reviews it has garnered. Will cook again and again!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
We really liked this recipe.  I tweaked it by using less than half the butter and removing the chicken from the pan after browning and adding some minced garlic to sautee with the mushrooms for a bit before deglazing the pan with the sherry and marsala, then adding the chicken back in and covering.  I also added a bit of cornstarch to thicken the sauce.  I also didn't use "good" marsala or sherry (couldn't find it in my grocery store and didn't have a lot of time to hunt) just the cooking stuff from the grocery store and it still turned out delicious for how simple it was to make.  Husband requested this be added into the regular dinner rotation.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I only gave this recipe 4 stars because it definitely requires a few changes to make it really good. More mushrooms are a must! I followed the suggestion to brown the chicken breasts, them remove them and sauté some garlic and onions, then deglaze the pan with the wine before putting the chicken and mushrooms in it. It works out really well that way. At the end, I add some milk (instead of cream) to the pan to make the sauce creamy, and to make more sauce. I find there isn't much left at the end. Adding milk makes it a nice sauce to put over pasta, and keeps it fairly low fat. We love it!

I'm giving this five stars because it is such a classic, no-fail recipe. Don't bother making this in advance if you are serving company -- the mushrooms are best if just cooked right before serving so that they have the right firmness. Very yummy! Best served with white wine -- because of the cooking sherry and marsala wine as ingredients I find you need something a little lighter than red wine to pair it with.

I always sautee crushed or minced garlic in olive oil before adding the chicken, because it seems to give it more flavor.  I double the sauce and pair it with homemade mashed potatoes and steamed asparagus. I like what someone said about avoiding cooking wines - it's true.  If they are not good enough to drink, they are not good enough to cook with.  Haven't found a need to add heavy cream and chicken broth to make it creamier, but it sounds good.  Excellent recipe that is both easy to make and fairly tasty.  Thanks!

text:
Pounded chicken in a large gallon sized ziplock bag, placed the flour, spices and mixed those together in a small sandwich bag. Dipped the chicken in milk and placed back into gallon sized bag then poured the flour and seasoning mixture. After coating all the piece I then added them to he olive oil and butter in th pan. In addition to the sherry and sweet Marsala (I find the dry makes it too bitter), I also added 1/2 can chicken stock. This was soupy but delicious over noodles. Next time I may try cornstarch to thicken it.

I've never done a rating for anything, but i had to for this.  All i can say is:  "Delicious.....deliciously delicious!!!"
I received an Oscar last night for this meal.  I substituted 3/4 sweet Marsala instead of using the sherry.
The chicken was soooo tender, they used butter knives.  I served this with potatoe au gratin.  Thank you to all my little people (my kids).

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/504042.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great recipe for chicken marsala. We both hate mushrooms, so I prepared the recipe without them. I used thin-sliced chicken breasts, as well as a combination of 1/2 cup dry Marsala wine and 1/4 cup chicken broth. I removed the chicken from the pan after browning, then added 2-3 T of leftover dredging flour to the butter-oil in the pan, cooked for a minute or 2, then added the marsala and boiled to thicken slightly before returning the chicken to the pan. Gave a nice body to the finished sauce! Garnished with freshly chopped Italian parsley before serving.

None
text:
This recipe is very simple to follow and turns out being delicious. I made a couple modifications- Instead of pounding out the chicken cutlets, I cut them up into 1" cubes and only used 3 tablespoons of a vegetable oil/butter blend. I do not use any form of "cooking" wine anymore because it is salty garbage and you can get a decent-sized bottle of regular dry sherry for around 5 or 6 dollars. Since I only very lightly coated the chicken pieces with the flour mixture, I added a bit more oregano, salt and pepper to the sauce when it was almost done.

country:
None
text:
I cut the butter (used I can't believe it's not butter light) and Olive oil to 3 tablespoons each since I was making only 2 large chicken breasts but kept the liquid the same and used a bit more mushrooms,.  I did not have sherry so I made up the difference with low sodium chicken broth and marsala wine.  I did use the seasoned flour on the chicken before cooking unlike some reviewers.  The sauce thickened wonderfully and the mushrooms were excellent - wish I had added more of them.  Something was missing though and will definitely have the sherry when we have this again.  Gave this 5 stars instead of 4 because I feel the missing ingredient might have been the sherry and it was super easy to prepare.  Next time I will cut the fat even more and try increasing the liquid becuase the sauce was so tasty on garlic and basil noodles.

text:
This was a delicious and easy to make recipe. It tasted just as good, if not better, than the chicken marsala that I remembered from a restaraunt that I used to always order from. I didn't have cooking sherry so I used all Marsala wine as someone suggested in an earlier review; didn't miss it because it was still awesome. I also fried a few slices of bacon I had left in the fridge in the pan with the butter and olive oil for an extra flavor kick. The chicken had a wonderful coating from the flour and the sauce was delicious. Thanks Lisa for the great recipe!

text:
Made for dinner after long day at work last night. Husband and I thoroughly enjoyed it, but it was missing something. I did what other reviewers suggested and added some cream and chicken broth. But it was bland. I think it needs more salt and maybe garlic powder. I also chopped up about 5 garlic cloves and added that right at the end of cooking time because we are huge garlic fanatics. That boosted the flavor. But it was still bland. The dish itself smelled amazing though and we did use dry marsala wine as opposed to sweet since this recipe didn't specify. It was quick and easy. Will add more salt next time and maybe even some green beans and potatoes!!! YUM!

text:
Great Marsala recipe. I like to make dishes as healthy as possible so I made a few adjustments: 1. I grilled the chicken instead of pan frying and then added into mixture as it simmered to absorb some of the flavor. 2. I didn't add any butter, just extra virgin olive oil. 3. I also added some garlic to the mushroom mix for extra flavor. Served with whole wheat bow-tie pasta and asparagus. Chicken Marsala is my boyfriend's favorite and he loved this!

text:
We loved this recipe! I added some garlic powder and cayenne pepper to the flour mixture and cooked it in olive oil then removed it from the pan. Added chopped onion with the mushrooms and doubled the liquid, cooked it down a little then put the chicken back in and let it cook another few minutes. I didn't have marsala so I used Zinfandel and it was a great substitute! Also used Thyme instead of oregano (not a big fan) and thought it added a great flavor. I thickened it with a water/cornstarch mixture. In the "keep" pile!

text:
Hubby had suggested Chicken Marlsala for dinner so I knew I could count on allrecipes to give me a good one. This recipe was was easy and quick to prepare .. I had to make a couple of small changes only because I didn't have 2 ingredients on hand. One I used all purpose whole wheat flour instead of white flour and basil instead of oregano. Sense I had only two chicken breast, I split them in half length wise and pounded them thin  .. As with several other reviews I doubled the recipe for the sauce. I also removed chicken from sauce and added whole wheat pasta to the mix tossing lightly with tongs .. Served with tossed green salad and small glass of the marsala wine to go with :)

text:
I browned the chicken for 4 minutes each side and transfered to another dish. Carmelize the mushrooms in the same pan and add a chopped shallot and olive oil if needed. Then add the sherry and marsala and reduce, then return the chicken to the pan and simmer for 5 minutes coating the juices on both sides of chicken. Let sit 5 min. before serving.

text:
Over all I feel that the taste of the sauce was exactly what I was looking for. I used to work at an italian restaurant who served the best marsala ever, so i have that to gauge it up to. The only downfall is the thickness of the sauce. I wanted to serve it over noodles but the sauce seemed so thin and brothy that I really wanted it to be thicker. I am not sure what I can use as a thickening agent to not loose the flavor of the sauce. Any ideas.


FYI-I learned from the restaurant that you have to use DRY marsala wine (good quality) and good Sherry. that is what makes the sauce after all. A good quality marsala and sherry wont run you up more than $15 bucks at the liquor store.

Review:
Rating:
3
dateLastModified:
2011-02-16T16:53:02.917
helpfulCount:
2
userID:
2402378
Display Name:
Erin
isPro:
False
followersCount:
20
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
149
favoritesCount:
890
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/46210.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I only gave this three stars because it basically required a total overhaul to get it to taste like the stuff you get in the restaurant. I tripled the recipe for the sauce (1 and 1/2 cups marsala plus 1/4 cup sherry) so it could be served over pasta by itself, without a side of pasta marinara. However, this came out with a very strong alcohol taste when I just followed the recipe. That's not the way this dish should taste. So I had to add quite a bit of chicken stock plus better than bouillon refrigerated chicken stock paste to give it more chicken flavor, swapped basil for the oregano, added approx two tablespoons of brown sugar and an extra tablespoon of butter plus about 1/4 cup heavy cream and a slurry made from mixing 2TBS corn starch to approx 4TBS chicken stock to thicken it. Oh -- and I sauteed a shallot and added that. I didn't have fresh mushrooms on hand so I used three cans of organic sliced mushrooms. After ALL that, I had a smooth, creamy, only slightly sweet & buttery sauce like the stuff you get in restaurants. So basically this was my own recipe just inspired by Lisa's. The sauce was good enough and thick enough to spoon over linguine.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2011-02-14T15:12:31.383

text:
I make a very similar version of this recipe. I flour the chicken without the oregano. Then I lightly brown the chicken, set it aside, sauté garlic cloves, then add the mushrooms and sauté the mushrooms. To the mushrooms I add about a cup of Marsala. I reduce the wine by half add about a cup of cream, return the chicken back to the pan and warm. Serve with rice.

None
text:
I put twenty whole peeled cloves of garlic in a large pan with 1/4 cup EVOO on medium heat. I browned the cloves but before they carmelized I moved them to one side of the pan and added the pounded chicken breasts. When the breasts were added I piled the garlic all over & around the meat.  When the breasts were done I placed them in a pan aside and made the sauce which I also doubled. Adding a little half and half and chicken stock then reducing down until it was the consistancy of cake batter then I added the meat back into the sauce. Quick easy, and wonderful! Chicken Marsala Masoero  mangiare!

text:
I made a few changes, and everyone LOVED it.  Before browning the chicken, I saute'd 1 cup sliced carrots til slightly crisp, along with a few minced cloves of garlic in a little olive oil.  Then I add the sliced mushrooms to cook a moment. Proceed with the recipe as specified, adding some heavy cream and chicken broth to the sauce.  Mix in a little flour to cold chicken broth for thickening the sauce more.  Also, adding 1/2# of cleaned shrimp to the chicken after it is almost cooked thru is a delicious complement to the taste.  Cook til shrimp is just pink and done.  Garnish with fresh lemon slices and fresh parsley sprigs.  Definitely great for serving to company!

Display Name:
Jen

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674149.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I give this recipe (my altered version) a full out 5 stars simply because I can't give it more!  I've made this so many times now that I don't even look anymore at the recipe. I use sweet cream sherry instead of cooking sherry.. I saute some red onions and garlic in butter, finely chop a couple of the total mushrooms and add those while the sauce is thickening (added flavor) add in a dash of lime juice and some heavy whipping cream to make it heavenly.  I also use chicken breast tenderloins and cut them into strips, rather than full breasts and do not use the flour.  When the pasta is done, I add in a dash of olive oil and a touch of lemon juice straight to the pasta.   This version makes a thicker creamier sauce and has enough zing to balance out the sweetness without overpowering the natural chicken and mushroom flavorings.  The wine is easy to balance out, no matter how much sauce you need. Use twice as much marsala as you do sherry. So if you need to use 2 cups of marsala, use 1 cup sherry, etc.   AWESOME AWESOME recipe!!  THANK YOU!!

This is the first time that i have been so compelled by a recipe that I have taken the time to write a review!   This was SO GOOD and SO EASY. text:
This was pretty tasty. I made very few changes to the recipe (I tried to stay as close as possible). I followed the advice of another rater and used a Ziploc bag to coat the chicken for easier clean up. I added some extra spices to the flour mixture-- basil, garlic, parsley, and marjoram. I also added fresh garlic to the butter and oil (we like garlic). The only change I really made was I didn't use sherry, but only because I didn't have any. I just supplemented with extra Marsala. I served it over penne pasta. It was pretty good, and I will make it again, but I'm going to play with the recipe. Perhaps next time I'll add some whipping cream to the remaining sauce! Thanks for a nice recipe.

text:
AMAZING!!!  A few things:  add garlic and onions to the olive oil/butter in the beginning, brown the chicken and then REMOVE it.  Then brown the mushrooms and add the wine and a few splashes of heaving whipping cream.  Add the chicken back in and turn the heat to low to help thicken the sauce.  This was GREAT!!!!  Super easy but a little time consuming.  WELL WORTH IT!  I also served the cheese onion garlic bread that's on this site too.  YUM

text:
Great!! I cut the sherry and replaced it with Marsala cooking wine. Also, I sautéed 4 cloves minced garlic in the butter before adding the chicken, added ¼ cup diced white onion to the mushrooms, and added a splash of heavy whipping cream and corn starch + water mix to the Marsala wine to thicken the sauce and make it more creamy. I also doubled the amount of mushrooms and sauce. Very good with mashed potatoes!

text:
Delicious.  I changed the recipe by browning the chicken first.  When browned I removed it to a plate and added the mushrooms to the pan.  I browned the mushrooms a bit and then added the wines to deglaze the pan.  I returned the chicken to the pan and simmered, covered for 10 minutes.  I removed the finished chicken to a serving platter and finished the sauce with a tablespoon of butter to thicken and a squeeze of fresh lemon juice for added flavor. I then poured the mushrooms and sauce over the chicken breast.  Served with wild rice and a vegetable.

GREAT!  Abe loved it (I did too) and it was sooooo easy!  I bought the pre-sliced and cleaned mushrooms.  Pounding the chicken took a little time but it was good stress relief ;-).  I used 3/4C. city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Oh my goodness! This was amazing! I've only been cooking for about a year, but this recipe made me look like a master chef in the eyes of my husband. I did make a few modifications though due to some suggestions of other reviewers. To keep it low fat, I only used about a tablespoon and a half of olive oil and no butter. Before browning the chicken I briefly sauteed the mushrooms with 2 large minced garlic cloves in a 1/2 tablespoon of olive oil. Then I removed the mushrooms and set them aside until the recipe instructed to add them. I used 3/4 cup of Marsala and no sherry. When the chicken was fully cooked, I removed it, leaving the mushroom Marsala sauce still in the skillet. I then used some corn starch in a small amount of chicken broth to thicken the mushroom Marsala sauce. Lisa, thank you so much for such an amazing recipe!!! Not only did my husband love it, but I am still licking my chops!

userID:
2955954
Display Name:
Alayna B
isPro:
False
followersCount:
2
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
136
favoritesCount:
5
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/220585.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was my first attempt at making marsala, and it came out perfect.  It tasted better than any marsala I've had at a restaurant.  I changed only a few things.  First, I added garlic to the butter and olive oil.  Once I browned the chicken, I removed it and set it aside.  I then added probably 4 cups of freshly sliced mushrooms to the butter/oil.  As the mushrooms were simmering I added a little over a cup of marsala wine.  I didn't use any sherry.  I then added a full can of chicken broth and about a cup of heavy cream.  I seasoned the sauce with garlic salt and pepper.  Then I added the chicken back to the pan and let everything simmer for about 10 minutes.  The sauce was the perfect consistency - not too thick and not too thin.  I then served the whole dish over angel hair.  There was plenty of sauce to go around - plus enough leftover to serve with the leftover chicken the next day.  This will definitely be a staple dinner in my house!

None
country:
None
text:
Very good.  Followed the recipe pretty close.  I made the mistake of only using butter to cook the chicken in.  The problem with that, is that the butter all cooked down and I had to keep adding more.  Really nasty looking pan.  I think I will do 3T of oil, and 3T of butter next time.  I also cooked the chicken, and removed, then deglazed the pan with 1 cup of sweet marsala, then added the chicken back to the pan, covered and cooked for 10 min.  I was prepared to add some cornstarch to thicken, but it wasn't necessary.  The wine glazed up and stuck to the chicken and noodles I served it over just perfect.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
LOVE this recipe. Will make it again and again. I use whole-wheat flour, and remove the chicken after browning. Then i add the mushrooms, onions, and some garlic. After cooking those a little, I remove most of it before adding the marsala wine. I don't use cooking sherry and it still tastes great. I just use LOTS of marsala wine.  YUM. After bringing that back to a simmer I add the chicken to cook. When finished, I remove the chicken again, put the mushroom/onion/garlic mixture back in, and add 1/4 cup milk. While heating this I sprinkle in a lot of the leftover flour mixture to thicken the sauce up. Delicious!

text:
The BEST chicken recipe that I've ever found. This is better than any Chicken Marsala that I've ever had in any restaraunt! Normally I don't care for Chicken Marsala but this recipe changed my taste buds. You HAVE to try this recipe- it's absolutely incredible! I serve it with the garlic mashed red potatoes recipe that I got off of allrecipes.com also. I also have served it once over long grain wild rice- and that is also super yummy as well! I always add a bit of the leftover flour mixture from coating the chicken to the wine sauce before serving so that it thickens the marsala sauce and it's a yummy gravy for the mashed potatoes or a great sauce to serve over the rice. ENJOY! :o)

userID:

Display Name:
Katherine

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614284.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This dish came out really great, just like restaurant quality. One thing I did that made the chicken turn out AWESOME was use a package of "Perdue Perfect Portions - Italian style." You get 6 filets, each one is about 1/4" thick, and they are PRE seasoned with italian herbs, so all you have to do really is coat each one with flour, you dont need to add additional oregano or other herbs. I took suggestions from other reviewers and added a tsp of minced garlic to the butter/oil (really added to the flavor), used sliced baby portabella mushrooms, added some onion slices, used double the amount of marsala wine (NOT marsala cooking wine, sweet marsala wine), added a splash of cream to the sauce, and added about 2 tsp of cornstarch to thicken it up a little. Served it all over garlic mashed potatoes, and it was really good! Everyone was impressed.

text:
This recipe is very good. I have made it a couple of times. The first time I made the huge mistake of making the sauce too thick and it was not good.  I recommend sticking to the recipe and adding more mushrooms and doubling the sauce, but be very careful about adding flour or cornstarch to thicken the sauce. If you need to thicken the sauce use wondra and do it very sparingly. I served this dish with the Aparagus with Cashews recipe from this site and everyone loved the presentation and the taste of everything - better than their favorite restaurant I was told. Thank you for such an easy and tasty recipe.

text:
This was dish delish! I am not the best cook by any means, but you'd never know eating this dish I made with this great recipe. My Italian husband said he would put it right up there with a great Italian restaurant marsala. The only things I did differently was I put some parsley in the flour mixture rather than oregano bc I don't care for oregano, and after I initially cooked the chicken, I took it out of the pan so I could fry the mushrooms a bit alone and then I added the chicken back in. I also did not have sherry so I upped the marsala to 3/4 of a cup. I served it over angel hair. 
THE BEST!

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3032832.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this recipe even easier and more South Beach friendly. I just defrosted frozen boneless chicken breasts, cut them into 1-1/2 inch slices and threw them in the pan with the oil and margarine. I sprinkled 1/4 C. of wheat flour mixed with salt, pepper and oregano over the top of the chicken in the pan and then stirred it around a bit. After the chicken had cooked awhile, I added in the mushrooms and onions and stir-fried until they were done. Then I added 1/2 C. of red wine, since that's what I had and let it cook on high heat until the sauce thickened some. It was a little purple due to the red wine, but everyone raved about how delicious it was and it was very quick and easy done this way.

This chicken marsala recipe was the best I've tried. It was very delicious and very easy. Great recipe and will be used again.

text:
I made this all throughout the summer (twice in one week, once), and it's still one of my favorites. I used red wine a few times (still turned out amazing) and I used an Italian spice blend instead of oregano. I definitely agree with adding more mushrooms. If you plan to refrigerate it (and eat it cold), though, use less oil/butter (down to 1 Tbs. each) so it won't solidify in the fridge...doesn't sound so appetizing in writing, but I'm sticking with what I said before: it's one of the best recipes I've ever used for chicken.

text:
This was delicious and very easy! I used 2 chicken breasts, an 8 oz. package of sliced mushrooms and served it over angel hair pasta. DH loved it and he's not normally a big fan of chicken! I usually cook with dry marsala, but since this also included dry sherry, I used sweet marsala and it turned out just right. Don't even think about using cooking sherry - it's just plain nasty! The only thing that I will do differently next time is to increase the spices a little in the flour mixture, due to personal preference. Thanks, Lisa! This one is definitely a keeper!

text:
Very good!!!  I changed a few things - I don't like breading so I skipped that all together and just lightly browned the chicken in 2 TBS of oil and buttter (each) and a clove of garlic.  I removeded the chicken and put it in a baking dish with some marsala wine and baked until finished.  I added the marsala wine (I used dry wine), another TBS of butter and mushrooms to the pan.  I cooked it for about 1/2 an hour and it was good but I like my marsala a bit sweeter - so I added about 2 TBS of brown sugar - AWESOME!  Definitely makes it so much better - my husband raved!  I used a lot of wine - I say just eyeball it and plan on using most of the bottle.

userID:
995166
Display Name:
cshrwd

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674134.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great recipe, with a few additions. I agree - the liquid/sauce isn't thick enough for my liking. Also, the butter used makes it a bit too salty, and the marsala sauce I prefer should have a bit of a sweet taste, and this lacks that touch. In order to thicken the sauce and bring the taste to my liking, I made the following additions: After the wine and mushrooms have been added in the skillet, mix 1/4 Cup low-fat buttermilk, 3/4 Cup water, 1 TBSP sugar, 1 TBSP cornstarch and 3 TBSP of marsala wine together. Pour into skillet and bring to a boil with lid off. Once rapidly boiling, add 1/8 TSP pepper and 1/8 salt to skillet. At this time cover, reduce heat, and simmer for about 5 minutes. This is great served over spaghetti or alongside buttered spaghetti noodles, topped with romano cheese.

text:
I've made this recipe twice. The first time I made it exactly as directed. The second time, I used all marsala and more mushrooms. It was better the second time. However, the sauce is missing flavor. I want to make this again and sautee some garlic before adding the chicken, maybe even minced onions. A sprinkle of salt and pepper at the end will help a lot too. The sauce is too thin for my liking. Adding heavy cream would help or some diluted cornstarch. It has a lot of potential but it is not perfect.

text:
This recipe was AMAZING! I am not a chef, although I like to cook and can follow a recipe. I made this recipe for 66 people at my son's Christening and EVERYONE RAVED about this chicken. EVERYONE!!! The only difference is that I did not pound chicken breast halves as my recipe called for 40 pounds of chicken and my arms could not handle pounding 40 pounds of chicken. I would not have been able to hold my son the next day!!! As an alternative I cut the chicken breasts into bite sized pieces which actually worked out a lot better for buffet style serving. Other than that I followed the recipe to a T and loved every bite... we ate it for the Christening, for lunch the next day and dinner the following night. Absolutely DELICIOUS! Thanks for making the food portion of my son's Christening a screaming success!

I love chicken marsala in general and this was excellent!  The only change made was omitting the oregano, just because I did not have any on hand.  Definitely will be making this again and again.  My family ate it all up...there was nothing left in the skillet.  

I chose to served it with foccacia bread & mashed potatoes.  It probably go well with noodles or rice as well.  If you are a vegetarian the mushroom and the sauce would be tasty. 

Thanks for sharing this recipe Lisa!

This recipe was simply delicious. For me and my fiancee's taste, I cut the amount of butter in half, doubled the olive oil, and the amount of marsala wine. userID:

Display Name:
MELCARP
isPro:

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614255.jpg
city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
My husband and I thought this was an excellent meal!  I am a bit challenged in the kitchen, but I was able to pull this off!  After reading the reviews, I did make a few changes such as instead of using sherry I used chicken broth.  I also omitted the oregano completely (We went to Greece a few years ago for our honeymoon where oregano is used too much in my opinion and now I stay away from it) instead I used garlic powder.  I also read were some people said this was too bland so I added a little extra salt and pepper.  I also doubled the sauce and the coating which was a good thing because I would have run out otherwise, but my chicken breasts were pretty big so I am sure that played a part.  I had also read where some people took the chicken out to bake to keep it form getting soggy so I decided to place two cooked breasts in the oven for a few minutes and cooked the other two as the directions said.  We ended up with two different meals, one with the chicken that was a little crispy that I put over angel hair pasta with spaghetti sauce and the other meal was with the Marsala sauce over the chicken and angel hair pasta.  Both of these versions turned out really well for us, but the chicken that I used the Marsala sauce on was so tender it was just falling apart, it practically melted in your mouth!  My husband rated this a 9 out of 10!  We will make again!  Thank you so much for the wonderful recipe!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
After reading several reviews of this dish, I decided to prepare according to recipe first and see how it tasted, except I halved the butter and olive oil, and in lieu of cooking sherry, just used Marsala wine for a total of 3/4 cups.  I agreed with several other reviews that the taste was rather bland, so I tried again, first marinating the chicken in a little marsala wine with salt, pepper, garlic powder, for an hour or so, increased the salt for the flour to 1 teaspoon and added some garlic powder and more black pepper to the flour. The sauce needed to be thickened so after completely cooking the chicken with the mushrooms, I took the chicken out and placed on plates, and added a can of cream of mushroom soup to thicken and increase the sauce as I was planning on serving the chicken over a bed of angel hair pasta and sauteed zuchinni (oil, a little salt, pepper, and a sprinkling of sugar). This turned out FABULOUS and delicious. Make sure to use good Marsala Wine--not cooking wine, but the one you buy in the wine section!

I took the advice of others and bought some sweet marsala wine from the wine shop. What a difference! Things I changed: I cut the butter and oil in half and it was still more than really needed . . . I skimmed some off. I threw in half of a minced shallot in the skillet before I added the chicken. After cooking for the 10 minutes, I took the chicken out of the pan, added some Wondra sauce and gravy flour (just a bit), and a tablespoon or two of half and half, and then let the sauce bubble just a bit. Then I served over the chicken. PERFECT!!!!!

text:
What a wonderful recipe for my favorite chicken dish!  One thing is missing, however: garlic.  The first time I made it I did not use any, and the dish was a bit timid.  Nex time, I added a couple of cloves of crushed garlic about halfway through cooking the chicken; it made a huge difference in the flavor.  One other addition: try topping the chicken with some deli hot ham chopped up a bit. (And don't cheap out on the brand of wine--kitchen brands don't do it justice!) A real restaurant quality dish!  Thanks for the recipe.

text:
I have made this recipe twice and love it each time.  I do make a couple of additions/changes.  I add minced garlic into the chicken while it is cooking.  I also use 2 cups of portebello mushrooms.  To thicken the sauce, I use a little bit of the flour mixture that was used to coat the chicken.  Then I serve it over angel hair pasta.  Next time I will serve it with bow tie pasta.  All in all...great recipe!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Outstanding!  At first, I read all of the reviews here, I decided to add chicken broth (half cup) with cornstarch (on your own measure) and it turned out great!!!  At first, 4 tablespoon of olive oil and butter didn't seem enough, so I added bit more.  I cooked chicken first then took them out when they turned brown.  I added Dry Sherry (House table, not the cooking one) and Marsala wine (Cooking wine) and sautee the mushrooms.  I added a lot for this (two boxes of sliced portabella and one box of whole mushrooms!)  When sauteed, I put the chicken back in the pan.  After looking at it, it didn't seem much sherry and marsala left in it, so I decided to add more.  I must have put in an extra cup of Marsala wine and half cup of Dry Sherry.  Let it simmer for awhile before putting in cornstarch.  Make sure you put cornstarch last in because it will turn thick immediately.   It tasted wonderfully!  It may seem like a lot of alcohol to you but everyone's taste is different.  Amazing dish!  (I probably put in too much alcohol due to a large cooking pan?)

This recipe was very easy, but I followed a few of the other suggested modifications:  doubled the liquids and mushrooms. I will make this recipe again, but I will keep the same amount of sherry and marsala (& do buy a good wine) and just add in a cup of chicken broth.

My husband went back for seconds!!

text:
I've never made this before and was looking for something different for my husband's Valentine's Dinner. LOVED IT!!  I did read some of the other reviews and made a few adjustments as well such as using the 3/4 cup Marsala instead of using the Sherry. I also added a ton more mushrooms, simply because I love my mushrooms! Hee Hee!!  Also since I added so many extra mushrooms I added about 1/2 cup of Chicken Broth and a splash of heavy whipping cream.  I also took the advice of cooking noodles and adding basil, garlic and olive oil to them, then I served the Chicken over the noodles with the sauce.
Will definitely make this again for sure!!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is really simple and adaptable to vegetarian chicken cutlets.. I used the new mycoprotein cutlets made by Quorn, warmed them for about 75 seconds, then floured and browned them in the butter/oil mixture. I did need to add an additional 2 ounces of water at the very end because the veggie cutlet absorbs some of the liquid while cooking. But all in all it came out very flavorful and moist. It is a welcome addition to my non-meat collection of recipes. Oh and I noticed in your video that you used white muchrooms. I used Baby Bella muchrooms to give the recipe a little more earthy flavor.

text:
I've made other Marsala recipes and this is the best so far.  I used chicken tenders instead so that saves having to pound out the chicken breast.  The cook time should be reduced too if you do that.  I browned and then simmered for  only 5 more minutes- leaving it to sit a couple of minutes more off the heat.

I also added green onions at the very end to add a bit of color, texture and I just plain like them.  

I added way more mushrooms as we really like mushrooms and it is really half the dish.  

I served over pasta.  Yum!

text:
Notes to self: Make it with sherry and marsala wine. You like  it better that way. When you didn't coat the chicken in the flour it was easier and less messy, but the sauce was thin. You can thicken the sauce with cornstarch and water or flour and water mixture. Make extra sauce. You can add some chicken broth to stretch the sauce.  You added a little cream to the sauce and liked it. Add extra mushrooms. Add some spaghetti water back into the bowl of spaghetti to keep it from sticking and to keep it hot.  Also add some sauce directly to the bowl of pasta and mix it in.

text:
I made this and I liked it but only because I did not use the  "cooking sherry" from the grocery shelf!! uck!!! Never use "cooking sherry or cooking wine" from the grocery!!  Its nothing but sodium and stuff that shall stay un-named!!  If you want to really favor this recipe and others that call for wines or sherries  you can purchase small bottles of sherries and red and white wines at the liquor store to cook with and the alcohol burns /bakes off so your not "boozing" up the dish! The sherries  and wines will store fine on your shelves - the reds don't last as long as the whites and sherries but  taste 10+ times better than that "cooking" stuff!!  And if you drink wine -- never cook with something you wouldn't drink! But you already know that don't you. LOL

country:

text:
I will definitely make this again. The chicken was moist and the dish had a smooth and sophisticated flavor. This recipe is very easy to make and doesnt require a lot of ingredients. I made the following changes: The night before I cleaned, pounded, needled and marinated the chicken in inexpensive Italian dressing in a ziploc bag. (I do this with all chicken breasts that I buy.) In the oil/butter mixture I lightly sautéed slices of garlic to flavor the oil. Removed and discarded the garlic before adding the chicken. (I learned this from Joy of Cooking's Becker's Brussels sprouts recipe.) Followed the remaining recipe as written except added half of a small onion choppped along with the mushrooms as suggested by another reviewer. I need to find more recipes that use Marsala wine and sherry. Really nice flavor.

text:
A new recipe for us to try and so good I had to go back for thirds! I did a few modifications too after reading others' reviews. I increased the mushrooms, wine, Sherry and seasonings in turn with olive oil and dairy-free margarine (milk allergy) and added minced fresh garlic and chopped green onions. I used a resealable bag for coating the chicken and removed it after browning before sautéing the mushroom mixture and added the chicken back in. To make a thicker sauce, I mixed together a couple tablespoons of corn starch with cold water and added a little at a time at the end of the simmer until desired consistency was reached and served it up on a bed of spaghetti squash. Excellent and a keeper for sure! Thanks y'all!

text:
I wish I had not waited so long in life to start making these type of dishes. Made it for wife and I, we loved it. I cut way back on the butter, maybe 1/4 of what was called for, 2 tablespoons of olive oil, and I took about 3 cloves of garlic and sliced it up thin to warm up in the butter n oil, huge positive. Cut the flour way back, used just enough for a thin layer but it thickened the wine gravy perfect.  Use a real Marsala Wine for $5.99 from Trader Joe's WOW!  Made mashed to serve with, used about 10 oz of baby bellas for 1 lb of chix breasts. Next time, double batch. Great staple dish to have in the rotation. Wife absolutely loved it, very satisfying meal. Will be making a lot.

This recipe was very easy and good.  I took the advice of other reviewers and doubled the Marsala wine and Sherry (not cooking wines). I removed the chicken while sauteing the onions and mushrooms in the wines and added a 1/4 cup of flour and spices to the sauce to thicken before adding the chicken back in.   I will continue to play with the sauce to perfect overall this was an excellent recipe and much easier than I thought.

text:
Delicious but I made some changes as others had indicated:
I used half the amount of oil/butter.  Added 2 minced shallots to pan when I added the mushrooms (I doubled the amount of mushrooms added).  Used all marsala wine, no sherry (added the two volumes together) and bought good quality marsala.  And to make it easier, I put all spices/flour into large freezer bag and added each flattened chicken breast to coat (like shake and bake).  Only added salt at the end, to taste.  Cooked the chicken a little longer than specified as I added 2-3 tbsp fresh chopped sage and 1/3 cup 18% cream.  Made it to serve 8 and was loved by all!

text:
Oh. My. Gosh!!! My husband and I love Chicken Marsala, but I've always been too afraid to attempt it for the fear of messing it up. I decided to brave this simple recipe last night for the first time and it was unbelievable!!! I'm actually a really good cook but no matter what I make my husband always has a suggestion for the next time. This time his only suggestion was to make more! I listened to the reviews and instead of adding the cooking Sherry I increased the Marsala wine to 3/4 cup and added about a 1/3 cup heavy whipping cream to make it creamier. I also doubled the mushrooms. My only suggestion is to double the Marsala sauce. This will definitely become a staple in my household and the meal for having friends or family over!

country:
None
text:
Did the cooking a bit differently.  Pounded the chicken so it was thin, then cooked as directed on one side.  When I flipped it, I put it towards one side of my (large) skillet, and added the mushrooms to the main part.  Salted those a bit and cooked them down for 8-10min on a lower temperature.  Then I added the wine and covered for another 8min or so.  I never get a good gravy from this, so I used 1T cornstarch mixed w/ about 1.5T water and poured in slowly until it started to thicken.  I didn't use the whole slurry - maybe 1/2 of it.  That gave me a great gravy.  Served w/ mashed red potatoes and roasted veggies (broccoli, onion, bell pepper).  Yum!

userID:
15215994
Display Name:
goodjuju

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674149.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Delicious!! YES!! I tweaked the recipe a bit. I quadrupled everything in the recipe, except for the butter & olive oil. I omitted the cooking sherry, altogether. I substituted the sherry for white wine vinegar. I could not fine Marsala wine, so I used red cooking wine. I added 2 large onions & 3 cloves of garlic!! I also added cream of chicken soup. 

This is the order in which I cooked everything:
1). I browned the chicken. I set it aside.
2). Using the oil that was left in the pan, I sauteed the onions & the garlic. I added a LITTLE bit of red cooking wine to break up the stuff on the bottom of the pan. I let that cook until the onions were soft.
3). I added the rest of the red cooking wine & the white wine vinegar.
4). I added epic amounts of mushrooms (we are a mushroom-loving family). I allowed that to cook until the mushrooms were cooked.
5). I added some cream of chicken soup to thicken the sauce.
6). I added the chicken back into the pan & allowed everything to cook together for about ten minutes. 

THE WHOLE THING TURNED OUT PERFECTLY!!! :-)
Review:

text:
This is a great easy recipe.  Very easy to make on a weeknight...I do all the prep and make side dishes and salads first, then as soon as this is done I am ready to serve.  I make this recipe ALMOST as is, with very minor changes, such as reducing the amount of oil and butter by half, using whole wheat flour, and more mushrooms if I have them.  It never disappoints and tastes like it was much harder to make than it was.

text:
I followed a couple reviewers' suggestions and made a couple other changes, and this came out very yummy.  I reduced the oregano to 1/4 tsp., used 1/2 cup of sunflower oil (instead of 1/4 cup butter and 1/4 cup oil), and I didn't have Marsala (and didn't want to use cooking sherry), so I substituted 1/4 cup sweet red wine and 1/2 cup semi-sweet white wine.  I definitely recommend making this!

text:
Delicious! My few changes: I used almost 2cups of baby Bella mushrooms. I was making an asparagus dish on the side that called for bacon sprinkled on it, so - not wanting to be wasteful- I used the same pan, with the leftover bacon fat instead of butter. I cooked the chicken for about 5 minutes on each side until just done & then set it aside. I cooked the mushrooms in the remaining bit of bacon fat & added the Marsala wine. I skipped the sherry. I wish I had more sauce & next time I will certainly double it somehow. After it cooked down just a little, I spooned it over the chicken. Every one loved it, including a 12 yr old & 92 yr old. Mmmmmm.

text:
Wow! I tried this recipe about a month ago and it turned out so amazing! My boyfriend went on and on about this dish. He didn't stop. He said it was one of his favorites. I changed it up a little bit. I used extra Marsala and Sherry wine and added cornstarch and water to make the sauce thick so I could pour it over angel hair pasta. I also used a whole container of mushrooms around 2 1/2 cups maybe. It turned out amazing! We both loved it! I also simmered the sauce and the chicken and mushrooms for about 25 minutes. It made the chicken melt in your mouth plus it absorbs some of the strong wine taste to which leaves you with a rich, tangy sauce. Awesome recipe.

I made this recipe for my fathers birthday. Except I tripled the recipe! I was cooking for 7 people and I tweaked the recipe a bit. The family loved this! Said it was better than going out to eat! Doubled the mushrooms and chopped up a small yellow onion to go in! Perfection! Display Name:
esadmf69

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614248.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
OMG, This recipe is AWESOME!! I have frequently enjoyed Chicken Marsala in Italian restaurants, but I just assumed it would be an ordeal to make it myself. I swear, this recipe is so quick & easy, you will be totally amazed. My husband and I have each made it several times, for ourselves and for guests as well. The mouth watering aroma as it cooks will have everyone thinking you're a total gourmet!  A few minor things we've tweaked to make it even better; we add a little crushed garlic to the oil & butter mixture just before placing the chicken in to brown. Next, we use extra Marsala & Sherry, (always with the 2:1 ratio), because we like extra sauce. We wait to add the mushrooms until the last time we turn the chicken so that they don't become overcooked. Finally, we whisk in a little flour during the last few minutes of cooking to thicken up the sauce and then serve this delicious dish over angel hair pasta. Add a salad & a bottle of wine, and you're all set. Be prepared for the compliments. Totally yummy.

text:
OMG!!!  This was great.  My husband went back for more!  I did follow some of the suggestions in the reviews.  I doubled the sauce..  actually using 2 whole cups of Marsala and no sherry.  I added a bunch of mushrooms and used some minced garlic out of a jar because that is what I had on hand.  

The marsala was from a wine and spirits store, not what you buy in the grocery store.  I used the real thing.  I also removed the chicken from the pan, sautéed the garlic and mushrooms, returned the chicken to the pan.  I used some cornstarch to thicken it a little and heavy cream.

I served the chicken with angel hair pasta and finished off the meal with a pan-fried asparagus recipe from this site.  No left overs with the exception of the little bit I put away in a container to take to work tomorrow before I served dinner.

text:
Ok... I followed it to the T except I had to use all marsala instead of sherry, because I thought I could find sherry at the grocery store and didn't want to go back to the package store where I got the marsala when I couldn't find the sherry... Sheer laziness, I know. Still delicious. The sauce was kind of blah after the chicken was cooked. Good, but... it could be better, so I chopped up a bell pepper and a small onion and threw it in along with some heavy whipping cream and OMG... It was so amazing. I am eating leftovers for breakfast... That good. I have absolutely no italian in me, so... sorry if this addendum to the recipe offends the sensibilities of true italian cookers, but it was so yummy. :)

text:
This is delicious!  So simple yet elegant.  I used brown rice flour to dredge the chicken - it's gluten free but the added benefit is that it makes the chicken almost silky.  Baby Bellas hold up nicely and adding a few sprigs of fresh thyme as the sauce simmers really adds dimension.  I'm 100% German but my Italian husband said, are you sure you're not Italian?  Definitely a keeper -- thank you, Lisa!!!

text:
I've got VERY picky eaters, and am kind of a wine snob, so I didn't think it would work (I could only fine Marsala at the grocery store - ack! - but it was DELICIOUS!  They were licking the bottom of the pan :)  I had to adjust a little based on what I had on hand, and even imperfectly it was good - next time I'm going to stick to the recipe and I'm sure it will be even better!  I didn't have mushrooms, and as another reviewer mentioned, I browned the chicken in the pan (I only had thighs not breasts), then transferred to a baking dish to finish at 375 for 15 min.  I had to use merlot instead of sherry, would have been better with sherry!  I tripled the sauce...for a family pack of boneless thighs, fed my 5 big eaters just fine.

country:
None
text:
Sometimes I make this dish with chicken tenders pounded thin. I saute my mushrooms first--sometimes days in advance. I buy those 1.5 pound boxes of 'shrooms at Costco, saute them, and they keep for weeks in the fridge. Then they're ready to add to sauces, omelettes, or any recipe that calls for mushrooms. I like to serve my Chicken Marsala with pasta, so I need lots of sauce. I add a can of chicken stock to the pan at the end, and lightly thicken it with just a little bit of flour.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/973977.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was very good. After I read some of the reviews, it seemed a lot of people liked more sauce. I took 1 chicken breast, trimmed off all fat and cut it in half. I pounded it out to about ¼ of an inch. Mixed Flour salt pepper and oregano in a bowl and coated the chicken. I melted 1 table spoon of butter and added 1 tablespoon of Olive oil in a pan over medium heat, browned the chicken on both sides. Took the chicken out of the pan and added Marsala, Sherry and mushrooms. The sauce turned brown and I put the chicken back in the pan to warm up. This was a very simple recipe to follow. 
Tips 
Cover the pan when sautéing the mushrooms with the chicken in the final steps.
To thicken the sauce I used a whipping cream.

text:
Great Chicken Marsala recipe.  I Didn't change any ingredients, just tripled the marsala wine, sherry and mushrooms because I love the sauce.  I also thickened the sauce by mixing 1 tbsp of cornstarch to 1 tbsp of marsala wine and mixing that in at the very end after the chicken breasts have been removed.  I butterfly the chicken breasts instead of pounding them out.  Just easier and faster that way.

text:
This recipe is very good and made a tasty dinner.  I read through some of the reviews before I made it, and I agree that it needed more sauce.  I browned the chicken on both sides, removed it from the pan, then added a sliced onion, sliced mushrooms, and a little garlic along with the wines.  To make a little more sauce, I added a cup of chicken broth with a little flour added to thicken just a bit.  Then I added the chicken back into the pan and put it in the oven for about 20 minutes to finish cooking while I prepared some rice and vegetables.  My husband loved it and took leftovers to work today.

text:
This was excellent.  The chicken was very moist and tasty.  I started with thin sliced chicken breast fillets and pounded them thin.  Instead of the oregano, I used 1/2 teaspoon of Italian seasoning, and I used 3/4 cup sweet Marsala and eliminated the cooking sherry.  I also added chopped green onions during the last 5 minutes of cooking.  I made 6 chicken breasts, and browned them two at a time, because my pan wasn't large enough for all of them.  I put them aside on a plate, and cooked the mushrooms down a bit before adding the wine and placing the chicken breasts on top.  Then, I covered the pan and cooked them for 5 minutes.  I turned the chicken breasts over, and added the chopped green onions, and cooked for another 5 minutes.  My family loved it!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've tried this recipe a few times, and because we don't have expensive marsala wine, I've modified it.  I marinated the chicken breasts in marsala cooking wine and white cooking wine for about 2 hours, seasoned the breasts with some salt and pepper.  This helped the flour mixture stick and give the coating a nice consistency when it browned.  This also helps the sauce thicken.  I used entirely marsala cooking wine (instead of the sherry), and added 1 tbs of sugar to the sauce.  Next time, I will make even more sauce (maybe 1.5 the suggested amount).  Marinating the meat helped bring out the flavor since the marsala at the store isn't very rich.  Top with some parsley and shredded parmesan reggiano.

text:
My only change is to prepare and drain fresh linguini, place the cooked linguini into the pan with chicken, mushrooms, Marsala n sheree, letting the noodles absorb all the flavors and add 2 big handfulls of baby spinach. Cover 2 minutes until wilted (bring heat down to med/low), then stir and serve. 
This is how they do it in The South.

text:
This came out generally well, but a few notes:  I tried adding garlic while I was cooking the chicken (per another review), but it ended up burning and kind of making a mess.  If you want to put the sauce over pasta, you're going to have to cook it down A LOT, and you're going to want to make WAY more sauce than the recipe calls for.  I ended up using practically the whole bottle of marsala wine, and I used a lot more mushrooms.  The sauce came out well.  I think next time I will use oil instead of butter to cook the chicken for health reasons.

text:
Made this for the first time and it was fantastic.  I have since read the reviews and realized I never pounded the chicken breasts.  Not sure what that does because it tasted delicious.  I don't eat mushrooms but my husband does and it didn't seem to make that many.  I would double or triple the mushrooms next time.  Cooking sherry wasn't at hand so I skipped it.  One reviewer said the butter wasn't really necessary, I would tend to agree but it did seem to make a nice thin sauce.  Thickening with heavy cream and cornstarch sound good too but that would just add calories.  Any marsala I've ever eaten in a restaurant came with a thin sauce not a heavy cream like sauce.  Basic is better!!

Delicious!  I made it lighter by cutting the amount of olive oil and butter in half and I didn't notice the difference.  I used twice as much wine and sherry and a whole container of portobello mushrooms to make a  lot of sauce to cover the mashed potatoes I served with it. text:
recipe makes a great base!  I added some garlic, chicken broth, a little cornstarch mixture and a splash of heavy cream at the end.  Fabulous!!  I really liked the mixture of the marsala and sherry in this recipe. I only had sweet Marsala and the sherry toned it down a bit.  Made this again...  I did not put the cornstarch mixture just cooked juices down a little more and was as good as the first time I made it!

text:
A very good chicken marsala. The only change that I had to make was substitute white pepper for black which I am allergic to. I also add fresh garlic most of the time. I found that using a sharp knife to cut horizontal slices made the chicken cook quickly and allowed the flavors to get aquainted in no time. Add lots of mushrooms and wine since it is so delish that you will want a lot. I have made this recipe many times and everyone raves about the flavor.

One Skillet Masterpiece!  We modified slightly to our taste.  Doubled the Mushrooms at the beginning and added 1 Cup of Heavy Whipping Cream at the end.
Finally, we tossed the Angel Hair Pasta with Infused Basil Olive Oil.  I actually think Egg Noodles would work just as good..but didn't make it with Egg Noodles, but will next time.
Followed up with the Steamed Broccoli as the original recipe states and WOW...we even have some leftovers.

text:
Loved it and so did everyone else.  I will be married 20 years next week and my husband never really liked my chicken Marsala. Today when I told him I made it for supper he made a face. I then told him I had a new recipe. He said he didn't like it but that he Loved it! and so did the kids. I did add some half and half to the wine and mushrooms , I all so put two cloves of garlic in with the butter and oil. After the chicken was done cooking I removed the chicken from the pan and then added mushrooms and wine. Cooked the mushrooms a bit added half and half then return the chicken to the pan. Thank you so much for sharing this it is worth its wait in gold

text:
This is an excellent recipe and I use it all the time.  I like my sauce a little thicker so I sometimes add a cornstarch slurry to the sauce because the flour on chicken is not enough to thicken.  Also if you can get a hold of real marsala wine and not the store bought one the dish will be SUPERB!  Only issue I have is the butter separating from the wines. and Im constantly having to try to mix the sauce.

This is a great recipe.  The only thing I do differently is making it gluten free with Pamela's Gluten free Pancake and baking mix in place of the flour. The original marsala wine and sherry were a little strong for me.

Fabulous dish! It is very important to make sure you DOUBLE THE SAUCE. It is so delicious and the recipe makes an amount that just teases everyone. A real people-pleaser, this one!

text:
Wondefful recipe! I did change just a few things according to other's reviews. I did sauté garlic first before adding chicken. I also doubled the sauce but next time I will quadruple it so there will be enough to put over pasta. My husband and I love sauce. Otherwise, I cooked it exactly as written, leaving the chicken in while mushrooms cooked. I think this added more flavor to the chicken. I also don't think it needs any extra flour to the sauce. The sauce was thick enough without it.

text:
This dish is amazing.  I cooked this as the main dish for a dinner party I hosted a couple days ago and everybody loved it.  I did make slight adjustments, though: I used more oregano because 1/2 teaspoon was definitely not enough.  I also cooked the mushrooms and chicken separately so the mushrooms wouldn't absorb all the flavor of the wine, leaving the chicken bland.  Baby Bella mushrooms, in my opinion, work the best for this recipe.

text:
Per the advice of other reviewers, I made a few minor changes and thought this dish was amazing!!  I LOVED it!  Before adding the chicken, I threw in a few pressed garlic cloves and half of a vidalia onion...then I doubled the mushrooms and the "sauce" - using 1 1/2 cups of marsala wine instead of the sherry - and at the end I added about a 1/2 cup heavy whipping cream to make a cream sauce....served over angel hair - YUM... healthy? NO...though I would say it's worth the splurge every now and then!!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've been making this recipe for years. It's so easy are great every time.  But I do change it up. I put the flour, salt, pepper, and oregano in a resealable plastic bag, then added the pounded chicken and shook it up (one breast at a time) to coat. It's just easier and cleaner that way.  When browning the chicken breasts, I added a few sliced cloves of garlic.  I doubled the sauce and mushrooms. Then thickened it with a slurry (water-cornstarch mixture) at the end so we could enjoy it over the pasta i served it on.  This recipe rocks!

text:
Yumm, yumm, yumm!  I did it just slightly different:  I left out the Sherry and used only Marsala; I used 2 whole packages of mushrooms to cram extra veggies in there; I skipped dredging the chicken in flour and instead just sprinkled with salt, pepper and oregano on the chicken itself before adding to the pan; I also removed some of the wine sauce while it was cooking, mixed in a little bit of flour to thicken it and mixed it back in the rest...thickened up perfectly and was delish served over spaghetti.  I'll definitely make again!

text:
This was fantastic.  Took the suggestions of others and cut back on the butter (2 TBS) and Olive Oil (3 TBS).  Also removed the chicken from the pan after cooking and deglazed the pan with liquids to make the sauce.  Added lost of extra mushrooms. Needed more sauce so added some chicken stock  and garlic and thickened with some of the leftover seasoned flour.  At the very end added a small amount of heavy cream.  Served over wheat linguine. My soon to be 3 year old kept saying "This is good, this is good!".  Very tasty.

Very flavorful! I adjusted the amount of Marsala and Sherry to accomodate more chicken. I also added minced garlic ans onions as the chicken was simmering. After smmering on the stove I added a little cornstarch flurry (cornstarch and water) to thicken the sauce and let it simmer in the oven for 10 minutes. text:
I followed the recipe on my first try and it was terrific, thanks to Lisa.  The second time I was cooking for a group and modified the recipe by increasing the number of breasts, forgoing the pounding, and marinating in a mixture of olive oil, soy, garlic, and wine.  I then floured and baked the breasts in the oven, adding the mushrooms and wines as recommended, and serving with angel hair spaghetti.  It was slightly different from the original, but worked very well for a crowd.  Everyone wanted the recipe and I referred them to Allrecipes.

This is the first recipe that came up on a Google search. Nearly 1900 reviews and almost all 5 stars - figured I couldn't go wrong. Coated the chicken in a Zip-Lok bag, used more oregano, some minced onion and garlic, doubled the mushrooms and more marsala and sherry. text:
Served it to company and everyone enjoyed it. I did the first step of pan frying the chicken before everyone came over and kept it warm in the oven. That way all I had to do when my company was here was to throw the chicken, wine, and mushrooms in the pan and cook it for ten minutes and serve.  I used dry marsala and dry sherry. It was very tasty but I did season it once it was on my plate. I thought it needed a little salt. I may season the chicken with salt and pepper before flouring it next time. Definitely try this recipe.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I had a horrible experience at a new restaurant when I ordered this dish, so I decided to make it at home for the first time and it is now a favorite for me and my boyfriend!  It was so simple to make and I'm not a cook....he is!  I doubled pretty much everything and added fresh garlic and onions which are staples in a lot of what we eat and I also removed the chicken after browning in order to cook the onions and mushrooms a bit more before putting the chicken back in.  I popped a lid on everything and let it simmer for at least ten minutes if not more to blend all the flavor and to make sure the chicken absorbed some of the wonderful marsala sauce before serving over some angel hair pasta.  I forgot to thicken the sauce which I'll make sure to do next time in order to cover the pasta better, but all in all a wonderful and easy dish to make!!!

text:
This was great!!! Too much butter though... Especially when advertised as a weeknight meal. We'd all have heart attacks! I used 1/3 cup olive oil and a tablespoon of butter.  Also, intead of beating the heck out of the chicken, I sliced each half breast so they were very thin.  I used WAY more oregano, most of which was fresh from my garden.  IMPORTANT: I used a 1/3rd cup more of each wine, and an onion that I added w the mushrooms to increase the sauce, to compensate for my lack of oil..    It was great!

I've tried other chicken marsala recipes but this one is my favorite.  The flavor is very good, and while I don't like mushrooms, I'll eat these!  I have a hard time flattening chicken, so instead I sliced the breasts in half while they were still slightly frozen. And as other reviewers suggested, I used a good marsala wine, which did make a big difference in flavor.

text:
Very good easy recipe.   I added 3 cloves of minced garlic and 1 chopped shallot with the mushrooms. You may also want to add a 1-2 teaspoon corn starch to thicken the sauce, especially if serving with pasta. Otherwise, the sauce, while mostly butter and oil, will sink to the bottom of the plate.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/54.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Thanks for this recipe. After reading several other reviewers, I made just a couple of adjustments. Added some additional "spice-age" to the flour mix (rosemary and garlic, primarily), browned the chicken breast, then removed it from the pan. I then sauted the mushrooms in the hot pan, (went easy on the mushrooms, though, as "The Hubbs" really doesn't care for them...) then deglazed with a full cup of the Marsala, reduced, then added a bit of heavy cream, then returned the chicken and simmered as directed. Flavors really married up nicely. Served with some garlic green beans and summer squash, plus a spinach salad.  Very nice.  Again, thanks for a good recipe.

text:
Fantastic!  I followed this recipe very closely, other than doubling the sauce because I wanted to serve it with mashed potatoes (will probably triple next time).  The only real change I made was that I got a little worried about the sauce being too thin so I decided to whisk in some heavy cream.  But the longer I let it simmer, the more I realized it would have thickened on its own anyway because of the wines reducing and the flour from the chicken pieces.  I used both the Marsala and Sherry and the flavor was amazing, just perfect.  Can't wait to make again, will make more next time so I can have leftovers.  Thanks so much for sharing this one, love it!!   [Update:  I made just the sauce tonight to try over steaks, I loved that too!  Yum!]
