text:
Everybody loved this!! I did make some changes. 1) I  put the flour and spices in a bag and shook the chicken, one piece at a time. 2) I added onion and garlic powders, Italian spices and used garlic salt instead of regular salt to the flour mix. 3) I put chopped onion and minced garlic in with the olive oil as I melted the butter. 4) I doubled the wine and sherry. 5) I added corn starch to thicken the sauce. Even those who didn't use extra sauce loved the flavor of the chicken.

text:
THis recipe has a strong wine flavouring I do not like. I added 1 cup water and omitted the sherry. Also I skipped the flour coating and instead breaded the chicken with beaten egg and seasoned italian breadcrumbs. First partially frying the cutlets till browned. Adds anice flavour and helps to thicken the sauce a bit. Family loves it this way. Mild flavouring for picky eaters.

userID:
4091086
Display Name:
Dawn Manor
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1429937.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent!!  This dish was a winner for my family.  Instead of pounding 4 chicken breast halves, I took 2 chicken breasts and slice them lengthwise through the center to make 4 pieces.  No pounding required and was enough for our family of 4.  I then mixed flour, salt, black pepper, & dried oregano in a ziplock  bag.  Shook each piece of chicken, next placing them in the buttered pan.  I didn't use oil and butter but rather substituted them with refrig. fat free/ calorie free Parkay spray.  Much healthier and tastes great!  After cooking each side of chicken, I placed them in a 250 degree oven to keep warm.  Using the same pan I cooked the chicken in, I added 1, 8 oz. package of mushrooms (I had to slice), some minced garlic, and dried onion.  After cooking this for a couple of minutes, I added a dry marsala wine (Colombo) but didn't used the cooking sherry and doubled it.  This measured out to be 1 1/2 cups of marsala wine, then I added 3/4 cup of Swanson's chicken broth.  Covered and let boil for about 15 min. then I added in a cornstarch/water mixture to thicken the sauce.  Lastly removed the chicken from the oven and into the pan to coat with sauce.  I made mashed potatoes and broccoli and there was plenty of sauce to add atop.  Definitely recommend to all, and again thank you Lisa!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This turned out very good! A few changes- I used half as much butter and olive oil (2 Tbsp each)-we really didn't miss it. Browned 2 cloves of pressed garlic before adding the chicken, halved the oregano and added a shake of basil instead, ended up cooking the chicken in 2 batches, put first batch in the oven on warm then when the second batch was ready added it back to the pan and added the wines, plus about half cup of chicken broth, simmered 10 mins flipping chicken half way through, removed chicken from sauce, turned up the heat to high for about 4 mins to reduce the sauce until slightly thickened (no cornstrach needed, add chicken back to pan for a min. Served over angel hair pasta, yum!

text:
This is great, but as with most, I made a few changes: I added about a half teaspoon of garlic powder (I had no 'real' garlic), I use cut-up chicken rather than individual breasts.  Also, it's pretty easy to cut down on the fat in this recipe (4T oil and 4T butter is a little excessive for four servings) by using a bit more Marsala (and I've never used the cooking sherry).  Also, last time I added a half diced red onion (I know this heresy, but it needed 'something') and it was delish.  A little worsteshire and/or a squeeze of lemon are both good, too.

This is my "go to" recipe for making chicken marsala. My whole family loves it. text:
Tastewise there is no need to change anything. I use less oil and butter for health reasons (we have copper-bottom pans that can cook efficiently without the extra fat). Don't skip pounding out the chicken. It makes such a difference, not to mention the chicken cooks faster. My son actually doesn't like this--he says it smells like beer. :) But he loves when I make it because it means he gets to hit raw chicken with a mallet and shout all the dead-chicken insults his 11-year-old mind can muster.

text:
It was very good and believe it or not I didn't have any Marsala so I used Port instead.  It was much better than the chicken Marsala I had the other night at an expensive restaurant.  If you don't have Marsala try it with Port.  I think it is just as good but different.  I plan to get some Marsala and try it again to see which one I like better.  Other than using Port I followed the recipe.  The sauce in a true Chicken Marsala isn't thick and absorbs into the noodles.  I used good whole wheat noodles.  I like whole wheat pasta.
Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2009-04-28T10:50:05.07
helpfulCount:
1
userID:
2450784
Display Name:
Katie
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
11
favoritesCount:
177
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/109359.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was good and will make again. The sauce was a little sweet for me, so I think a pinch of cayenne may be good to balance it out. I browned the chicken well, then set it aside and started the sauce. I let the mushrooms cook in just a splash of chicken broth and the fond from the chicken. After about 8 min, I added the wine/sherry and let that cook for a few more min. Then I added about a half cup of chicken stock with a few tablespoons of non-dairy sourcream (toffuti is the best brand on earth, my husband can not have regular). When the sauce was nearly reduced to the preferred consistency, I added the chicken for a few more min to warm up. I served with fettucine tossed with a butter/lemon/garlic/sherry sauce (basically what you would use for shrimp scampi).

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is so tasty!  I have made this for several dinner parties and everyone raved about how moist and wonderful it was.  Make sure to pound the chicken out evenly and to at least 1/2 inch so it cooks quickly and doesn't burn on the outside.  I would recommend doubling the sauce so you have a little extra to serve over garlic mashed potatoes.  I used a thermometer to cook the chicken to keep it from being over done and dry and then transferred it to a big electric roaster while I finished preparing the rest of the chicken (I did a party for 24).  Every single piece was eaten and people were asking for more.  Thanks to whoever submitted this recipe!  It has become a favorite of mine.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/147604.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Fantastic recipe- definately a keeper! I read some of the other suggestions and kind of put my own spin on the recipe. Heres what I did. Followed a previous posters idea to "shake" the chicken in a ziplock with the flour mixture. I used the very thinly sliced chicken breasts so I would not have to pound them out.  Then I followed the directions and added (when I added the mushrooms and liquids) a clove of freshly grated garlic, (no sherry- I just added some of my resiling wine in the fridge instead). I also added freshly chopped parsley and a few squeezes of lemon to the sauce, oh and about 1/8 cup of fat free half and half to thicken it some. I served it over whole wheat pasta, with risotto and grean beans. Thanks for the recipe!!

text:
Lovely recipe.  I gave this a 5, because I am sure the recipe would be good on it's own - I made the changes to suit our taste/lifestyle.  I made it exactly as written, except only used the olive oil, added a slurry of cornstarch and water to thicken the sauce,(the heavy cream that others suggested looked wonderful, but oh the cholesterol, and hubby had a heart attack last summer!), and made double the sauce to serve over pasta (linguine tonight, who knows next time?).  I also eliminated the salt, per my usual the first time I make a recipe, but will add it to the flour mixture next time, since there isn't the salt from the butter.  Served with steamed sugar snap peas and a simple spinach salad.  Thanks for such a tasty , quick and easy recipe!

text:
I would definitely reccomend trying this dish if you are a fan of sweet chicken marsala. My husband made this recipe for me for a date night he planned. I picked it off the website, he made it. He is a good cook and has the mind of an engineer-so I trust he followed EXACTLY what the recipe says.  We both enjoyed the meal but our expectations were very high after reading the reviews and we felt slightly let down. Both of us ended up adding a bit of salt, and both agreed it tasted like SOMETHING was missing but couldn't figure out what. I also found myself longing for more mushrooms. That is why I gave this dish 4 instead of 5. I would reccomend any marsala fan give it a try though.

text:
So good just like one of my favorite restaurants! Followed recipe as is w/ some additions. Boiled pasta while cooking chicken. Grilled chicken with addition of 1 tbspn of minced garlic. Once cooked through, removed chicken and     mushrooms (1 pack of sliced Portabella). Mixed 1 tspn of corn starch in water and slowly added to sauce to thicken. Tossed in whole wheat pasta and 1/2 cup of chopped parsley (or to your liking). Wow! Highly recommended!

text:
This recipe is quick, easy and delicious.  I also add sliced onions and garlic with the mushrooms.  I've made this several times and didn't always have sherry and marsala wine so I've gotten creative with my substitutions.  I've used double the wine instead of sherry/wine.  Some times I didn't have sherry or marsala so I used chardonnay and even white zinfandel in a pinch.  Each time it comes out very flavorful.  I highly recommend serving with mashed potatoes.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614242.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this yesterday for Christmas.  I had a group of people over - one didn't like turkey, one didn't eat ham, another didn't eat beef etc.  This made a good Christmas dinner - elegant, easy and everyone liked it.  I breaded and cooked the chicken (8 servings) the night before.  Christmas day, I made the sauce and then put the chicken back in to simmer in the sauce.  It was ready sooner than I expected, so I put the whole thing in the oven to keep warm. I also made several changes to the sauce. I cooked four green onions and a half teaspoon of minced garlic with the the mushrooms (more garlic would be good but I wasn't sure my guests liked garlic).  Like others here, I substituted Marsala wine for the sherry.  Because I didn't make the sauce in the same pan I'd cooked the chicken in, I boiled a bullion cube in a half cup of water and added that too. I also took the suggestion of another reviewer and added a little cornstarch and a few tablespoons of cream at the end.  Great!! Everyone loved it. I will make this again!!

city:

country:
None
text:
I made this for my then-boyfriend-now-husband about 3 years ago for our first date and he said it was the best he'd ever had, including from a restaurant. I tweak it slightly: once the chicken is browned and the mushrooms added, I take the chicken out, add about 1/4 cup of heavy cream and 1/4 cup of chicken broth. Let it reduce for a creamy sauce. I serve it over angel hair with Classico Traditional Basil Pesto (in the pasta sauce aisle, very small jar, top shelf of Food Lion if you shop there!). Great recipe!
***EDIT: I forgot to mention that I cut the chicken into thick pieces/slices and coat them individually - it makes this dish much more "user friendly" and also adds flavor as each piece is seasoned. Enjoy!

text:
This was simple to make. I doubled the sauce to serve over pasta. I also doubled the mushrooms. I took the advice of others and added chicken broth, heavy cream, and a  little corn starch to thicken the sauce. I also marinated the thin slice chicken breast with worchester sauce, garlic, and onion for 10 minutes before dipping into the flour batter. If you leave the floured chicken in the fridge for a few minutes it will help the flour stick better when frying. The dish came out wonderful.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was great, but of course I tweaked to my version as a lot of people do. I added onion powder to the flour mixture.  I used a touch of garlic oil with the olive oil and butter in the pan. Used half the butter as well. After browning chicken, I took them out and threw in a shallot and some garlic..Sauted quickly and then added mushrooms. You may need a little more olive oil..I season with the spices at each step. I used baby bellas and a variety package..Different types of shrooms will change the dish.  I then threw in the Marsala and Sherry which I tripled..Let this cook off for a few minutes, add the chicken and simmer until chicken is cooked.  I served with garlic mashed potatoes..Drizzling the sauce over them was heaven!!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/63499.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Yummy.  I used a little over 1/3 cup of flour to bread the chicken, and what I did was I placed the 4 chicken breasts in the flour/seasoning mixture, saw that I had a lot left over to use, and I sprayed the coated breasts with Parkay spray butter, then recoated them to use up any excess flour.  I used garlic pepper instead of regular, and I used about 1/4 tsp. of Nature's Seasonings.  Also, I added about 3tbsp. of half-n-half to wine sauce, and about 2 tbsp. of flour to thicken the sauce up.  I added the flour before the mixture became to hot, as the flour will clump up if you stir it in while the sauce is boiling.  Based on these modifications, the entree was delicious.

text:
Simple, quick and delicious.  I use this recipe a lot.  One thing to note is that the recipe does vary due to what kind of marsala and sherry you use.  The first time I made it I used cooking sherry.  Strangely enough, I think that was the best and produced the most flavorful meal.  But for the most part, I use what I have on hand and it really does make a difference.  I've used both dry and sweet marsala.  Amontillado, cream sherry, etc.  Adjust to your liking..

text:
My husband and I liked this recipe.  When making this meal, I did make some modifications. I added more spices to the flour mixture to give the chicken more flavor.  I increased the amount of seasoning that the recipe called for and added some garlic powder and basil.  I also browned some garlic in the oil and butter before adding the chicken.  I added some fat free half and half and chicken broth to the sauce to make it creamier and richer, and I also thickened up the sauce with a slurry (cornstarch and water mixture) so that it could be served over low carb linguine.

Overall, I found the dish very flavorful and easy! I will definitely make again.

Update: I tried this dish again. With more olive oil and no starch or broth, the sauce came out perfect. The only negative now is that it needs much more sauce than the recipe calls for. Pretty good... I upped the spices, used a lot more portabello mushrooms, and added a little corn starch and chicken broth. Subtracted the sherry and added a little more marsala. Tasty... not perfect, but that's probably more because of my lack of skill. Relatively bachelor-friendly meal.

Display Name:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I did my own thing with this recipe and made it so easy. I slice my chicken breast and seasoned flour it then combined butter and olive oil to cook up the chicken. Once it all is browned nicely, I add the marsala (lots more than called for) and baby bella and white mushrooms sliced really thin. The flour on the chicken thickens the sauce nicely. I then serve it over rice.

This is a wonderfully easy recipe! I followed it exactly, except I removed the chicken from the pan at the end and let the sauce cook down for another 10 minutes, which made it a little thicker. It was delicious and even rivalled the Chicken Marsala at our favorite Italian restaurant! I'll definitely be making this again!

text:
This was great because it was so easy to make, and the chicken was perfectly moist and tender. The only changes I made were that I added a little garlic powder and onion powder to the flour coating and I used baby bella mushrooms instead of white ones. However, I wouldn't receommend making those changes because there's no need to add spice, and bellas have a robust flavor that doesn't need to be added to this already flavorful sauce. I too added some flour to thicken the sauce, and it was delicious! I'll definitely make this again soon.

Wow!  This dish is amazing.  Perfect for special occasions, and so easy to make.  I cut the butter and oil in half, doubled the mushrooms, doubled the wine and sherry, and added cornstarch mixed with cold water at the very end to thicken the sauce.  Instead of using chicken breasts, I used chicken tenderloins which are flatter and cook faster and more evenly.  Thanks for this recipe!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a good way to stretch chicken if you're on a budget.  I used four breasts, but after pounding they were huge so I cut into 4 pieces each.  It could easily serve 6 if you had good side dishes.  I had to do the chicken in two batches, but used the same butter and oil both times (and I halved that).  I took the chicken out to a platter after simmering for 10 min and then the sauce simmered alone for a bit and didn't look thick enough so I added a little cornstarch-- but I wish I hadn't.  Next time I'm going to leave it thin and put it over the chicken and also ladle a little on each serving.  I served with vegetable cous cous and steamed broccoli.  Definitely a keeper!  Tasted restaurant quality!

Display Name:
SHEINSHINE

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614260.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was a great, quick, easy meal that had a lot of oomph.  I liked that it can be served as a weekday meal or used for company dinners.  The recipe was great and I changed very little about it.  The coating for the chicken was good, but I tend to like Nature's Seasoning instead of plain salt and pepper.  It adds a kick of garlic and onion.  I increased the oregano to taste -- probably doubling the stated portion.  I let the butter froth before adding the meat to clarify it and used quality olive oil to achieve that rich flavor. I didn't have sherry in the house (how did THAT happen??), so I simply left it out.  Used a GOOD marsala wine recommended by the local liquor store owner.  I did add a bit more of this than the recipe called for to increase the sauce, as well as some low sodium chicken broth.  After removing the chicken, thickened the sauce with a touch of corn starch for that extra body gravy.  Wow.  Quick!  Yummy!  Husband loved it!

Some changes for next time: more mushrooms, less butter and oil, more salt and pepper and maybe some fresh garlic.  I served it with fresh asparagus and rice pilaf.  A lovely, easy meal!  The good wine and sherry is the key as well as really tenderized chicken.

text:
Made this last night,  used brown rice for the base,  made in instant pot 1-1 ratio 15 manual 5 min natural release, then quick release, no heat after the 15, was perfect for two cups.  Anyway, added shallots to the sherry and marsala, mushroom step, just that bit more flavor.  Don’t be scared to add more marsala and sherry if needed.  All in all good dinner.  Of course I had to have spinach.

The recipe should specify to use sweet or dry Marsala wine. I used dry, which must be the wrong option. Also the wine sauce never thickened like the sauce I’ve had in restaurants.  I added a bit of flour to thicken it & used twice the mushrooms since they  cooked down so much.  This recipe needs to be tweaked for improvement.

userID:
26586349
Display Name:
AnyaJ
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/7520209.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I followed some other recommendations (using 3/4 Marsala wine, no sherry, and dusting the chicken breasts with the flour/salt/rosemary in a Ziplock bag) and it came out very light and flavorful! I had my doubts about sautéing the one side of chicken until light brown and then cooking the other raw side with all the Marsala wine present, but it worked out great! I let the raw side simmer on medium heat for 8min and then flipped. I let it simmer on that side for another 3-4 minutes and the chicken came out soft and juicy.
Review:
Rating:
3

text:
I modified this recipe a little bit. I just put a half a cup of the cooking marsala wine and left out the Sherry. After the chicken and mushrooms were done, I took them out of the liquid and put it in a measuring cup and beat in 1 tablespoon of flour until it was smooth then I poured it back in the pan and let it thicken. When I served it, I topped it with the cream sauce and mushrooms. It was very delicious and Looked great.

country:
None
text:
A decent marsala recipe. 
a couple things I did - I used a gallon sized ziploc bag to coat the chicken in the flour seasoning. I also bought good marsala and sherry wine (not the ones specific for cooking). I removed the chicken from the pan after browning before adding the mushrooms and wine, then gently rested the chicken on top, covered, and finish cooking. 
I served it with egg noodles and mashed potatoes - the marsala sauce was a delicious gravy for the potatoes.

country:
None
text:
As others have suggested, removing the chicken to saute the mushrooms in the pan; adding some garlic after the mushrooms have sauteed a bit; and using some of the leftover breading flour to thicken the sauce are great suggestions. (I also added some half-and-half at the end, but I'm not sure it made much of a difference.) I also simply sliced my chicken breasts thinner instead of pounding them.  I love recipes that are a great base for building on, and this is one of them. The fact that you can go from start to finish in about half an hour means this recipe will enter my family's dinner rotation.

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614254.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is the second time I try this. My husband loved it and told me this recipe was a keeper. The first time I followed the recipe faithfully. This time I added a bit more salt, pepper and oregano to the flour to give the chicken more flavor. I was able to make 6 thinly sliced chicken breast fillets with the same amount of sauce. Because I had extra minced garlic from a pasta I made to accompany this and I read a review that mentioned they had added minced garlic when browning the chicken, I decided to throw it in. This was at the end, however, when all the ingredients were simmering. I’m so glad I did! It enhanced the flavor nicely. Next time I’ll add the garlic at the beginning. Overall this is a delicious recipe that I’ll be doing over and over again.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674139.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I changed it up. Removed meat after browning, Deglazed with 1/4 cup dry sherry, 3/4 cup Marsala,  added mushroom, lowered heat,  added 1/4 cup heavy cream, salt, pepper brought to a boil, then replaced meat, lowered heat, covered and simmered. To finish, rolled a knob of butter in the flour and added to sauce stirring until blended. Fantastic!

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was an easy and delicious dish to make.  I removed the chicken after browning it, added a couple of splashes of heavy cream in with the mushrooms, stirred it up and returned the chicken a couple of minutes later to simmer covered.  Due to cooking for 12, made it in 4 batches and kept portions in a foil pan in a 180 degree oven until ready to serve.  Served over angel hair-reserved a cup of the water the pasta boiled in and added that back to the pasta before spooning over some of the marsala sauce.  Served a party of 12 with rave reviews.

None
text:
I blended this recipe with Chicken Marsala II and other people's comments by adding 1 can chicken broth and 1 c. cream to extend the sauce. I also sauteed pancetta, 2 cloves garlic, and 1/4 c. chopped onion for flavoring in the base of the sauce. A pinch of Italian Seasoning and Parsley helped give it a boost and added a bit of green to the sauce.  After frying the coated chicken in olive oil, I kept it warming in the oven while I made the sauce, then brought it all together with angel hair pasta. Delish.

Made 2 simple changes; added 1/4 cup half n half, didn't use any Sherry.  I didn't measure the mushrooms but used a bunch. I would recommend using a lot of mushrooms! All that much better! This recipe turns out very high end like and yet is so quick and easy. Definitely will make again and again! A suggestion for those that don't want to pound the chicken, when partially defrosted, slice very thin slices. Works like a charm.

text:
Well....I must say, this recipe was very easy. The reason I gave 4 stars is I should of known better, but 4 T of olive oil along with 4 T butter was wayyyy to much for us. I had grease floating in my sauce, which that has never happen to me before on other Chicken Marsalas.  If I ever make this recipe again, I would cut back on the oil and butter. And, yes, I did use the seasoning and flour for the chicken. Anyway, otherwise, for me, I would go back to my other recipes on Chucken Marsala. I had to try this one because of the high reviews. I love Allrecipes and make many of their recipes, esp Chef John.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5900201.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
We enjoyed the chicken marsala.  Thank You!  first time trying any chicken marsala recipe...
I followed the recipe but felt like there was too much butter and olive oil, and not enough marsala and cooking sherry.
After covering the pan, it didn't seem to cook down enough in 10 minutes so I cooked it down to where it seemed to be a nice thicker sauce.  When we tasted it, it seemed like something was missing...I remember some sweetness in the chicken marsala that I "craved", so I took out some natural maple syrup and poured about a tablespoon on the plate next to the chicken.  After taking a piece of chicken/sauce/mushroom and dipping it in the maple syrup, all the flavors came together (at least for us) in the way we were looking for them to come together.

I've made this twice. The first time I followed the recipe as is, and I wasn't impressed. So, this time I tweaked it... 

changed/added the following:
didn't season flour - just seasoned the chicken with salt, pepper, garlic powder and lightly floured
1cup Marsala
1/4 cup cooking sherry
1/2 cup heavy cream
1/2 cup freshly grated parmesan  

-- after sautéing the vegetables, I added those ingredients together to make the sauce. 

added prosciutto 
1 small vidalia onion
1tsp freshly chopped garlic
2 packages of mushrooms

side of asparagus
Review:

text:
My son is doing the cooking these days, so I am always on the lookout for simplified versions of my favorites. This is a great example. He flubbed a bit on flouring the chicken, but even so, it was quite good. If you like lots of sauce, you might want to double or triple the wine, broth and amplify the seasoning a bit. This has a nice glaze, but not copious amounts. Even our recent mushroom convert was impressed!

text:
Amazingly delicious!! Very easy to make!! Only thing I would add to the directions is letting the sauce simmer and reduce after chicken is cooked for a thicker sauce. Or add in a little bit of heavy whipping cream, more flour or milk to help thicken.  The sauce will be very thin/watery if you don’t do one of those added steps.

It was delicious!  I doubled the recipe.  I used Italian bread crumbs instead of flour. text:
This was a delicious, easy recipe! I Will make it again. I usually feed 8 for dinner, so I added more chicken. When the chicken is cooked, I move it to a pan with a rack in a 275* oven. It will hold for more than an hour. When I cooked garlic, added beef broth and marsala wine, I let it simmer , covered for 30 min. To thicken the gravy I used “ tapioca flour” mixed with water. Instead of a thick ( flour) gravy, the “ tapioca flour/ water mixture into bubbly liquid mixture. It thicken like a glaze. Delicious!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My new favorite! Changes: ***DAIRY FREE RECIPE***I used all butter (earths balance) instead of oil. I didn't like how it came out with oil the first time.  I Cooked the chicken with half the butter (4tbs) and set to the side. Added the other half of the butter (4tbs) and sauteed mushrooms. Then I added the wine. I used all marsala wine and doubled it. Added chicken back in, covered and simmered for 10 min. I removed chicken again, added 3/4 cup of coconut milk and added the  left over flour mixture from the chicken. Simmered until thick and served over angel hair with chicken. Full filled my craving and got me hooked!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3971319.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Sauteed the chicken, removed from pan and set aside.  Added a little minced garlic, mushrooms, marsala wine and sherry and let it simmer- I did double the amount of ingredients for the sauce.  Added a little chicken broth and heavy cream, as well as a little cornstarch to thicken.  The sauce had a very strong wine taste, so I added a little more extra cream to it.  Added the chicken breasts back to the pan and let it all simmer for a few min.  Served on top of fresh linguine pasta, with a salad and some fresh crusty bread.  Delicious!

text:
Quite good, but I prefer using my recipe that deviates slightly.  I don't coat the chicken with flour, but use an egg wash and Italian Panko crumbs.  Also use 1 cup of chicken broth, and use ½ c of that to thicken (with 2.5 T flour.)  DO NOT eliminate the sherry!  That ingredient boosts the flavor to real restaurant quality.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674153.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this receipt as suggested and LIGHTLY COOKED  the chicken BEFORE  placing the mushrooms and other ingredients in the chicken pan to start making the sauce ASSUMING that the chicken would cook all the way. It did not turn out as planned and while the sauce cooked the chicken never cooked all the way and ruined the whole dish.  PLEASE COOK THE CHICKEN ALL THE WAY SEPARATELY BEFORE YOU BEGIN THE SAUCE PART.

I also added garlic and heavy cream to make the sauce creamy and that made a big difference.
Review:

5

userID:
3340099
Display Name:
Aliza Crespin Lee
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1222112.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Absolutely delicious! I would have given it five stars but I had to make some minor changes.  I dredged the chicken in the seasoned flour mixture and browned in olive oil and margarine.  Then I removed the chicken.  I then scraped all the brown bits from the pan and added lots of fresh garlic.  Sauteed for about a minute.  I then added the mushrooms and sauteed  a bit.  Added a full cup of marsala wine and a half cup of the sherry.  I let it reduce a bit then I took a little out and mixed some flour to make a paste.  Added that back to the mushroom sauce.  Added the chicken to the pan, and let it cook about 10 min till the sauce was thickened and chicken was cooked through.  Spooned sauce over the top of the chicken. Serving with some basmati rice.
Review:

4

text:
Followed the recipe very closely.  I did add some garlic (about 1 tbsp minced) to the butter and oil.  I also used 3/4 cup of marsala and no sherry (since i didn't have any).  i also used almond flour for coating the chicken.  Instead of pounding the chicken, I cut boneless skinless breasts in half horizontally to create two thin pieces.  In preparing, I took the chicken out of the pan while cooking the mushrooms in the wine.  Then I poured the wine/mushrooms over the chicken and served over rice.

text:
Most recipes on this site are creations of the cooks & chefs who enter them, most ... but not this recipe.  Chicken Marsala is a classic french recipe and if you are going to put things like eggs or capers, then you should give it another name and make it a new recipe!    Also, never use cooking wine to cook with ... if a wine isn't fit to drink then it isn't fit to cook with either, use a good broth instead.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/872109.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I followed this recipe to a T and it was delicious! I doubled everything in the recipe, except the chicken, so I would have enough sauce for a box of linguine. I used a huge frying pan I keep in the garage so the ingredients would have room to cook in the pan and the pounded chicken wouldn't be needed to cook in several batches causing some of bits in the bottom to burn. I even doubled the coating on the chicken because I wanted to make sure with doubling the liquid it would thicken up enough. This was so easy and so good! I have tried several Marsala recipes that called for broth and I thought it was a key ingredient, however those recipes seem to lack a depth of flavor. I was concerned that the sherry would give it too much of a bite and it wouldn't be good, but it absolutely made the dish! I also bought Holland House Marsala and Sherryl because that's all the store had and I was worried that I didn't have better quality wine, but it was perfect! Try this recipe as is and you won't be disappointed. It is the only Marsala recipe I will ever use from here on out! Thanks for sharing. Enjoy!

I have made this a number of times and it is delicious. I generally reduce the sherry to a dash and substitute chicken broth because otherwise we find the alcohol taste too strong. I also add a little more liquid (3/4 cup Marsala and 1 full cup chicken broth) so we have extra to pour over spaghetti. I also add some garlic and onion powder to give it a little extra flavor. It is a crowd pleaser!

text:
I used dry sherry instead of cooking sherry (cooking sherry and wine is full of sodium and other additives) and added a bit of garlic (shallot would taste good, too.)  I kept some chicken broth with a bit of marsala and sherry mixed in so that in case the cooking liquid boiled off too much, I could replace it. This came in handy the second time I made it. Keeping a bit of the seasoned flour is a good idea in case you want to make a thicker sauce at the end of the cooking time.

I love chicken Marsala and love the addition of sherry in the recipe. The only thing I change is not coating the chicken with flour. I always end up with a lumpy sauce. None
text:
I really enjoyed making this recipe.   I doubled the recipe because I had extra chicken breasts, and drained the sauce off after cooking the wine and mushrooms with the chicken.  Then in a small pot, I cooked the sauce with a can of chicken stock, some garlic, onion salt, a bit of sugar and some cornstarch to make a decent amount of gravy.  This way, the chicken was saturated with the Marsala flavor, and I had lots of extra sauce/gravy to put over the pasta I serve the chicken with.  It was really good and my family raved.  I would have given it 5 stars, but I like a stronger sweet Marsala flavor than this created.  Still really good though!

text:
This is a really great base recipe.  I, as others have done, opted to add some things (more seasonings in the flour, and thinly sliced onion in the pan), and shook the chicken in a bag to avoid the mess.  I also used Pinot Noir instead of Marsala wine.  I like the flavor, and it seems to pop more.  Don't be afraid to let this simmer longer than 10 minutes.  Wait for the right consistency of the mushrooms and sauce; then, it's ready.

This was totally the bomb!!!  I followed the example of some other reviewers and added onions with the mushrooms after taking the chicken out and setting it aside, then a couple of sliced garlic cloves before deglazing the pan with all Marsala wine. text:
So what is the big deal between the "cooking" marsala and real marsala wine?  The rule is "if you won't drink it, don't cook with it".  So I bought both.  And man, I can tell you, buy the real wine!  The cooking marsala was salty and had no body.  Like others suggested, I used only marsala, no sherry.  I added onions and garlic.   Triple the sauce!  I served with broccoli and fettuccini noodles.  Next time I will make with French green beans as I feel the broccoli was too over powering.  The focus of this plate should be the marsala!

userID:
20489987
Display Name:
Zoe

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674169.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Honestly not that good of a recipe. My mom makes a wonderful chicken marsala but I didn't know how and instead of asking her beforehand I thought to try an online recipe... Mistake One. The chicken turned out with a soggy breading because of the wine and didn't actually absorb any flavor. Apparently breading or four-ing the chicken isn't a popular opinion, so Mistake Two. It ended up tasting like a normal chicken with soggy wine flour pieces. Afterwards, I asked my mother how she usually makes it and apparently it's almost backwards from this recipe.
First, she pours the wine into the skillet and heats it up a bit, then adds the mushrooms to it. Once that's cooked a bit she adds the chicken pieces, which she has not breaded or floured (with good reason), and lets that cook until ready.
By the end, the chicken has actually absorbed a lot of the wine and is perfect to serve over a nice pile of rice or pasta.
So Third and Final Mistake was not actually asking how she made it before trying it myself and expecting similar results.
Rating: Would not follow THIS recipe again but chicken marsala is just too good to not try and make again, properly this time.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2016-10-21T01:06:09.45

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I give this 5 stars for the method this is prepared and cooked, at the last minute i realized i did not  have Marsala wine but really wanted to try this recipe. I did everything exact until it came time to add the Marsala and mushrooms, instead i added "Mushrooms in White Wine Sauce" by LINDALL on this site, it was close and a great substitute when you are in a bind like i was. The meat was so tender do not skip the pounding it is worth it, i dont have a meat mallet so i laid wax paper over the chicken and used the long side of a can of soup to pound. The combo of the oil and butter made a great base for the sauce and made it restaurant quality. I pulled half the butter out of the pan before it melted realizing that it would be way to much, i also used unsalted butter. Thank you for the great recipe, cant wait to try it with the correct wine! Try this with the slow cooker mashed potatoes from this site.

text:
I made this with just two large chicken breast. They just fit in a very large skillet after pounding them flat. Also I wanted to have extra sauce to use over small spinach and cheese raviolis. I doubled the mushroom, used all marsala (3/4 cup) no sherry and added just a little heavy cream to the sauce (good suggestion). I cooked the chicken and removed while I cooked down the mushrooms and made the sauce. I then added the chicken back in for a few minutes. The only thing I would change next time is to season the sauce with salt and pepper. It really needed it.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very flavorful chicken in this easy to make Marsala dish. I used fresh chicken tenders instead of the breasts, so the meat was nice and tender. I recommend making on a night where you might not have a ton of time to spend in the kitchen but want a tasty and healthy meal. 

The only step I would omit the next time I make this dish, and I will, is flouring the chicken. Once I added the wet ingredients and let the entire dish simmer, the flour coating turned a bit soggy - not a fun texture for the palate. 

P.S. I added a small, sliced white onion and served with a side of creamed spinach.

text:
Awesome! Followed instructions almost exactly but used chicken tenders as thats what I had. Also used one big pkg of Bella mushrooms and since I didnt have any sherry on hand I subbed out Chardonnay for it. That admittedly made it a bit sweet so I cut the sweetness back by adding about a 1/4C 2% milk. I also added about 2 tsp chopped garlic. Served over white rice and the kids gobbled it up. They actually enjoyed eating chicken! Amazing :)

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3386382.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is very good although the first time I made it the sauce was too thin and there wasn't enough. I followed some tips from previous comments. I threw 3-4 cloves of garlic halved in the butter and oil and removed once brown. Then browned the chicken. After browning the chicken I removed the chicken from the pan set aside.  I then doubled the sauce(Marsala wine and sherry) and added a little more butter(2Tbsp). Then added the mushrooms, some heavy cream and some cornstarch to the sauce. Cooked for about 10 mins and added the chicken back in about 5 mins through to reheat. My family is absolutely loved this dish.

text:
This was my first time making  Chicken Marsala ever and so for that reason I followed the recipe to a "T". 

First of all, I  found the photo misleading, and could have been because of the brand of sherry or Marsala cooking wines. 

I was disappointed that the sauce was thin and not thickened up at all. I was told that it was because of the flour not being made separately, using the cooking wines, as many Marsala recipes do.

My guests and I really liked the flavor. In the future  I'll be trying another recipe or modifying this to make the sauce thicker.

This recipe was OK, but I also modified it.  After I cooked the chicken I removed it from the pan and added the mushrooms and onions the the pan.  When the onions started to look transluscent, I put the chicken back in the pot and increased the marsala wine ro 3/4 cups and added a 1/4 cup of cooking wine.  I added twice the mushrooms and served with a spinach salad.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made the recipe exactly as directed and it was fantastic! I've never been one to order this at a restaurant, but I've had friends who were obsessed with this dish. Now that I have this recipe I will never order this out, it's so easy and tasty! My whole family, including my picky toddler ate this up. I served it alongside angel hair pasta and zucchini.
I think it really helped to use both the masala wine and sherry. I also use real butter and extra virgin olive oil. Fake butter /margarine has an odd taste to me.
One shortcut I used was to out the flour mixture in a zip lock bag and put the chicken in the bag, shake it up, and voila, totally dredged with easy cleanup. I always do my dredging this way.

text:
My family and I enjoyed this recipe. I did make some modifications. Yes, I have unusual tastes, but adding figs really made this recipe pop for me!  I added about 10 chopped up dried figs. Will use fresh figs next time but I happened to have a can on hand.  I used cornstarch with just a little flour for the breading to make it nice and light and crispy. Also added a whole quart of fresh sliced portobello mushrooms, doubled the Marsala wine and sherry and added about a tablespoon of minced jarred garlic.  Enjoy!

userID:
9278922
Display Name:
katiewinkler
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:

8

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674163.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I gave it 5 stars because it's a good base recipe. I Does need some garlic and onion added and after reading the reviews, that's just what I did.  I added 2 cloves of garlic and finely diced 1/2 of a small/ medium onion. After pounding them flat, I covered my chicken breasts well in the flour mixture (I used my Gluten Free baking mix) before putting them in a hot pan with a couple tbsp. Grapeseed oil (grapeseed oil is better at high heat than EVOO, I typically use my cold pressed EVOO for salad dressings and some baking).  A few minutes after turning my chicken over I added 1 & 1/4 cups of  what I had which was Dry Marsala Wine. Sweet Marsala Wine was recomended to me by a chef so I improvised with 1 tsp. organic sugar (since this dish at the local itallian chain is Slightly sweet). I added the mushrooms, garlic and onions on top and put the lid on for everything to finish cooking.  The chicken breasts were done in 5 minutes with the lid on so, I plated them up and put my mashed potatoes beside them. I let the sauce cook another 5-10 minutes. I Did ad a couple more tbsp butter, since I added more Marsala to the recipe, and a splash of the whipping cream. It looked thick enough but, I made a cornstarch slurry w/1 tbsp cornstarch and 1/4 c water, stirred it well and added it which, instantly thickened it some more. I spooned the sauce over my chicken (which was nicely browned) and mashed potatoes!  I would try it wo/ the cornstarch next time as, I don't think it needed it. This

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3173570.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this recipe and it was quite good. If you're making a lot (16 servings for the family) be sure and use 2 pans and put only half a cup of butter in each pan. You also don't need much olive oil. I added some curry, parsley, more pepper and a bit of cayenne pepper to the mix and just put the chicken in a zip lock bag and shook the bag to coat it. Muuuuch easier. I also added a whole onion as well as strips of a yellow and red pepper. This not only improved he color but the taste too. It was absolutely delicious. Add the onion and bell pepper when you add the mushrooms and let it simmer. Remember I used one white onion, as well as one yellow and one red pepper to make 16 servings so plan accordingly with that. Enjoy! (I served this with curry rice and it went with it spectacularly)

text:
I double the mushrooms, and add 2-3 crushed cloves of fresh garlic.  Also use 3/4 cup Marsala wine, and 1/4 cup Sherry, or just 1 full cup Marsala if you have no Sherry.  Don't buy the cheap grocery store wine, though.  Get a good Marsala and Sherry from the liquor store.  That will make all the difference!

This was my first time making chicken marsala!!! I've always had it at Olive Garden never home made. The only thing I changed was using all Marsala wine instead of the cooking sherry. Also I used French onion soup after sautéing the mushrooms and garlic to kinda deglaze the brown bits then added the wine. I only used the soup b/c I was feeling lazy and didn't want to cut up any onions. The soup kinda thickened the sauce so I only added a pinch of flour. But it was very good and I can't wait to eat my leftovers tomorrow.

text:
I loved this.  I used a large cast iron skillet to make this. I cut the chicken into strips and then put in the flour. Then I cooked all the chicken first. Removed to bowl then sauted the mushrooms and sliced onions, when they were done I put them in the same bowl as the chicken. Then I added 2 cups of Marsala wine and reduced it down (too much) so I added 1 cup of half & half.  Stirred quickly to make the sauce and then added in the chicken, mushrooms, onions. Yummy and super easy!

text:
This was a great recipe! There are a few adjustments I made to it. First, instead of putting the mix in a dish or shallow bowl, I put it in a bag. Makes for less cleanup that way. I doubled the butter. I removed the chicken after browning it so that the mushrooms, which I doubled, could be sauteed in the butter. I doubled the wine and sherry and added a splash of heavy whipping cream. Added the chicken back in and then simmered.

Display Name:
Seneca64

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614260.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was good but not to-die-for fabulous. Our Sprouts market sells chicken cut thinly for scallopini so I used that and did not flatten the meat. I didn't have Marsala wine so I used Marsala cooking wine instead and added the cooking sherry. Because the cooking wines seem salty to me, I didn't add salt to the flour mixture. I'm glad I didn't--I think the dish would've been too salty otherwise. I used less olive oil and less butter because we want to avoid extra calories and the amt. I used (probably half of what was called for)was adequate. Awhile back I came across a screaming deal on sliced fresh mushroom--a huge bag for hardly any money. I divided them into several bags and froze them. For many recipes they've worked fine but in this case they seemed rubbery and that detracted from my enjoyment of the dish. The hubs didn't seem to notice and voiced no complaints--in fact, complimented the dish. I served it with rice because hubs requested it and there was quite a lot of sauce.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great recipe. I followed what others said and put the flour and seasoning in a zip lock bag. I cut the chicken into medallions so they'd cook faster. Since I love mushrooms, I doubled them, and added some onions and garlic at the same time. I also thickened the sauce in the end after taking out the chicken pieces with a cornstarch slurry and a splash of half and half, because it's nice to indulge every now and then. Oh, and if you don't have sherry, use dry vermouth as a sub. 5 stars for the recipe poster and those leaving comments.

text:
I really liked the flavor of this recipe, and how uncomplicated and precise the flavor profile was. I can't imagine putting cream or cornstarch in this, as others have suggested. That just seems like a sludgy mess to me. However, I do have two thoughts. First, I forgot to put the oil in, and I don't believe anyone missed it at all. Halving the fats was in my mind the mistake I made that made this dish for me. Also, I agree with others who said that more mushrooms would be better. Let's get the fungus among us.

After reading all rave reviews, I was so looking forward to this dish. I liked the chicken itself but not the sauce. I actually couldn't stand the sauce at all. I've had chicken Marsala only one time and I don't think I was too fond of it and I guess this just proves that I just don't like chicken Marsala. I'm not a drinker so the strong alcoholic flavor made it worse. I followed the recommendations(cream, chicken broth) which should have diluted the alcoholic flavor but not quite enough. I liked the chicken itself a lot so I would have to find a different type of sauce for the chicken.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is very good even without the sherry.  Quick easy, and the best Marsala dish that I have ever made.  I've tried making Chicken Marsala a few times before using this recipe with some poor results, but this was nice.  I made sure to remove the chicken from the pan after the fry on both sides.  I then threw in about 3 cups of mushrooms (could have been more)and sauteed them for in the butter and oil a minute before adding the Marsala.  I also added the remaining flour mixture to the Marsala mushroom mixture before replacing the chicken in the pot for the final simmer.  Nice dish.

text:
Super yummy and VERY easy to make, this dish looks elegant as well and is great for formal dinner parties. Made very minor changes, used thin cut chicken cutlets which did not need to be pounded down thinly. Seasoned the chicken with garlic powder, salt and pepper, then floured the chicken. Only used 2tbsp of butter and olive oil, and bought good marsala wine from the state store. I did not use the sherry just added more marsala wine. I doubled the fresh mushrooms and added onion and fresh garlic. This is a keeper my husband and I loved it. You will not be dissapointed.

text:
Recipe was great!  I made a few easy changes. I pounded the chicken thin and then breaded it (dipped it in flour, then egg wash, then bread crumbs). I also used about 1/4 cup more Marsala wine & a little more butter; just to have extra sauce. I served it over tagliatelle and my husband LOVED it. I will definitely make this again. It was quick & easy.

7204927
Display Name:
WCsinger09

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674154.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The reason I gave this 4 instead of 5 stars is, I'm sure, because I did not buy high-quality Marsala wine.  Here is what I did:
Flattened the chicken breasts on the cutting board underneath plastic wrap.  I put the flour mixture in a jumbo Ziplock bag and alternated adding chicken pieces and a little flour.  When all the pieces were done, I sealed the bag and shook it up.  I then browned the chicken and set it off to the side on a plate.  I added probably 1 1/2 cups wine to the pan, along with the mushrooms.  I let it reduce for a minute or two, then added the chicken back in.  I turned the chicken once, simmering for probably 15 minutes while I made risotto.  I turned the heat down to low and added a few tablespoons of half and half and mixed it in.  The chicken was wonderfully browned and so tender I cut it with a fork.

text:
This chicken marsala is so amazing.  I made it for New Year's Eve and it was a big hit with everyone!  I made a few small changes to the original recipe.  Tripled the mushrooms, used less olive oil and less oregano.  Browned the chicken and then removed to a baking dish.  Made the "gravy" in the pan.  Made extra gravy to serve with my mashed potatoes and added a bit of half-and-half to smooth it out.  After cooking for about 10 minutes in pan, poured it over the chicken and popped it into the oven for about 30 minutes.  Turned out perfect!  Happy New Year!

I made this for my husband and I tonight. We both generally like Chicken Marsala but I'm a pretty picky eater so I was skeptical but this recipe was very to cook, didn't take long and was amazing. The sauce was a bit thin as I think I didn't get enough flour on the Chicken but not to the point of being a downfall. The chicken was flavorful and tender. Definitely would recommend.
I would say though that it is worth it to track down a Marsala that isn't a cooking wine.

text:
I make this Marsala Recipe in a French oven. It comes out perfectly every time! One thing that I found was when cooking with a French oven as you simmer it covered it really keeps all the moisture in, so I have to remember to pull the lid off about halfway through the simmering time. Other than that and a splash of half-and-half that I add near the end, this recipe is perfect.

text:
This was really good! My Italian husband loved it, even though he didn't love the smell as it was cooking. We both don't like mushrooms, so I omitted those. Instead of the cooking sherry, I used 2 teaspoons of vanilla extract. I also added Italian seasoning, and a lot of pepper and salt to the flour mix. I fried garlic in the oil before browning the chicken. I finished off the chicken in the oven for 1/2 hour at 350. Served it with spaghetti with a butter/parsley sauce and it was great!

text:
This was really good stuff.  I followed the advice of others and used the plastic bag for the coating mix, used 3/4 cup of marsala and left out the sherry.  For my own twist I added 1 cup of chopped, roasted, red peppers from our garden.  Also, I doubled the mushrooms and thickened the sauce with a little bit of 1/2 and 1/2 and a teaspoon of cream of tartar.  My husband and I really enjoyed this and cleanup was minimal for a meal that seems a little elaborate.  Now, what to do with all the leftover Marsala...

Display Name:

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2239997.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I use the same recipe and it is great.  I soak the chicken first in buttermilk for about 2 hours, pat the chicken with paper towels to remove the buttermilk and then put the chicken in the flower mixture.  After browning the chicken breast, I then add the mushrooms and Marsala wine and simer everything for about an hour until the sauce thickens up.  If it gets too thick, just add a little chicken stock to the sauce.  I also never pound the chicken breast flat - I have nothing against the chicken breast; why pound it.

text:
I liked this recipe. It turned out tender, which doesn't always happen for me with pan cooked chicken. Because I'm pregnant and being cautious to not consume alcohol, I did a substitute for the Marsala wine. I used 2 Tablespoons red wine vinegar, 1 Tablespoon vanilla and then filled up the rest of the 1/2 cup with white grape juice. It turned out well! Oh, and my daughter is allergic to dairy so I used shortening instead of butter, which I do a lot, and that worked very well also. Thanks for the recipe!

userID:
8777625
Display Name:
Craw4d4

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674136.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
So...I tried this recipe for the very first time last night...AMAZING!!! I absolutely LOVE chicken marsala and have longed to have the Olive Garden classic right here at home and thanks to Lisa, I now have it!!! After reading a few of the reviews I made a few suggested changes. I mixed it in a ziplock freezer bag (much cleaner), I added garlic powder, salt, pepper, and onion powder to the oregano/flour mix. I cooked the chicken separately from the marsala cream sauce. I started the sauce in a nonstick pan with about a teaspoon of olive oil and a tablespoon of butter and threw in some onions and fresh minced garlic with the mushrooms(I am typically not a mushroom lover, but baby bellas are my new fav)and marsala wine and I added cream and a little flour to thicken. I eliminated the sherry and used two cups of marsala wine. I cooked the chicken longer as well (not a fan of under-cooked meat) and eliminated about half of the oil and butter. This was absolutely wonderful and did not take long at all... I WILL use this recipe again soon. Delicious. Oh, I served it on angel hair pasta with a side of steamed spinach.. I am a very picky eater and so is my mother BUON APPETITO!
 ;-)

userID:

Display Name:
NomNom

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674167.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Like many others, I also modified the recipe a bit. I wanted to use up all my mushrooms from my fridge, so I used 2 c. instead of the 1 c. (I recommend this if you like mushrooms.) I also sauteed the mushrooms with 2 cloves of minced garlic before I added the wine. I listened to the other reviews and doubled the amount of wine- there would not have been enough sauce otherwise. I wanted to avoid cooking wine, but I could not find Marsala at the store. I stuck with the cooking wines, but I also added some Pinot Noir I was drinking at the time. I simmered the chicken in the wine/mushrooms as the recipe called for, but then I removed the chicken and thickened up the sauce with some cornstarch in cold water before adding the chicken again. I served this over egg noodles. Everyone in the house loved it. It was my first time making a wine sauce; I was surprised at how easy and delicious it was.

This recipe is easy to make and absolutely yummy!  Definitely worth it to spend a few extra dollars on good marsala wine and cooking sherry.  I sauteed onion and garlic before browning the chicken and added cornstarch to the sauce to thicken it. My friends loved it, as did I!

text:
This was very fast and very easy so 3 solid stars. The finished product was a little disappointing. The flavor of the sauce seemed a little ‘sweet’ and lacking in complex. Could have been my fault. I did add a splash of heavy cream and additionally, I used more mushrooms than called for plus used a tiny bit of cornstarch slurry to thicken it. But it did not have a deep rich Marsala flavor. I bought the most expensive dry Marsala that I could find. At any rate, it is good enough to make again, and I will try letting the sauce simmer longer and maybe adding more ‘green’ herbs and a little chicken stock. Thanks for a really easy, fast recipe!

text:
I made this for a pot luck with an Italian theme. Instead of the whole chicken breasts I used strips 1 1/2" - 2" long. I followed the recipe by coating and sautéing the strips. I added the rest of the ingredients and when finished I added it to al dente pasta (I used camepanelle), stirred it all in and took it in a crock pot to keep it warm. Everyone loved it!  It was so quick and easy and this preparation was perfect for pot luck style.

text:
Made this twice. Loved it both times but this second time I decided to add capers and sun-dried tomatoes. I also thickened the sauce a tiny bit with a bit of cornstarch mixture.The only other change I made was I cooked the chicken then removed from pan as it was done. I would suggest a more drier Marsala wine with less preservatives and salt.

text:
Very good!  I used the redommendation to add a splash of heavy cream and a cornstarch/ water mixture to thicken.  Also added a tbs of minced garlic to the butter/ oil before putting the chicken in.  I used a large portabella mushroom cut up instead of smaller ones.  I would say 1.5X the sauce, not 2X.  I used marsala only (sub the sherry for more marsala).  I added half a package of fresh spinach (rinse, remove stem, boil in 1 cp of water and drain, add with the mushrooms).  Served with mashed potatoes. Will definitely be making this again soon.

text:
This is a staple classic for our family. Like other's in reviews I added Italian seasoning to the flour and only used marsala wine ( doubling it) (omitting the sherry) I doubled the mushrooms and added  a whole medium sized sweet sliced onion as well as fresh minced garlic when adding the fresh sliced mushrooms. I tripled the  amount of sauce and thickened it with a can of cream of chicken soup and a few teaspoons of the left over flour. I served it over garlic mashed potatoes and a side of steamed yellow squash.
 My family went gaga over this recipe, Thanks for sharing!

Very good recipe!  It was easy to make and a big hit!  I did take the advice of some of the other reviewers.  I doubled the butter and oil and added 1/2 cup of heavy cream and 1/4 cup of the "dredge" flour at the end to make a sauce for pasta.  I also crushed one glove of garlic and added it also, with some extra salt. I will definitely make this again:)

text:
This is REALLY good!  The only thing that I did differently was add goat cheese:

After I browner the chicken in the frying pan, I put the chicken breasts in a casserole dish and put dots of goat cheese on top.  I then used the same frying pan to sauté the mushrooms and added the wines.

After the wine and mushrooms reduced a bit in the frying pan, I poured the sauce on top of the chicken and goat cheese in the casserole dish and baked at 350 for 35 mins.

Thank you for the great recipe!

This is a really easy and delicious recipe.  I used baby portabellas and added a few more of them than the recipe says.  I also finished the sauce by stirring in some half and half, which made it much more rich and creamy.

inotes

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I left out the oregano and sherry. I cooked the chicken on med-high heat and put on the side to rest while I made the sauce. I added 1/2 a shallot to the pan with the mushrooms, then the Marsala. I let it reduce uncovered until 1/4 the amount. Then whisked in some cubes of butter, added fresh parsley and spooned over the chicken. If I need to stretch the sauce I add a demi glace or chicken stock after the wine is reduced.

This is the perfect recipe, delicious and easy.  I have made it several times now.  I made it for out of town company and had to give her the recipe. The only things I have changed are doubling the amount of mushrooms and adding some chicken broth to thin the sauce.  I chop the chicken into bite size pieces and serve over bow tie pasta.  I also sometimes add steamed broccoli or asparagus to the chicken and make a meal. Yum.

text:
The entire family LOVED it!  It was so easy that my 10 year old daughter did most of the work.  It made her very proud to serve this tasty dish.  I added garlic before the chicken as well.  I also doubled the sauce.  Using real Marsala wine opposed to the little bottles found by the oil and vinegars made a HUGE difference! I did add heavy cream, but I still wished the sauce was a little thicker.
I put it over thin spaghetti with asparagus chopped into 1 inch segments.  The asparagus was tossed in butter and garlic for a few minutes then added to the pasta.  YUMMY!

Tried this when I was looking for a quick tasty way to prepare 2 lonely chicken breasts that had been guilting me silently from the freezer for weeks. Had to make substitutions for the Marsala wine and sherry (not the most sophisticated array of cooking wines in our house...I used a bit of cab franc and a splash of bourbon for sweetness), and I threw in some sliced red onion on a whim. text:
I made 48 servings of this.  It was easy but I didn't flour it before cooking it and used olive oil instead of butter.  Everyone loved it!  I think it's better plain rather than over pasta.  If you are going to put it over pasta, you need to add some chicken broth and half and half to the pan at the end after removing chicken.  Also I top it with parmesan cheese over pasta because the pasta makes it a bit bland.

2010-11-15T16:16:19.527
helpfulCount:
0
userID:
4224837
Display Name:
CKG
isPro:
False
followersCount:
2
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
9
favoritesCount:
34
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/7539232.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was a delicious and easy recipe. I give it 4 stars only because even with some modifications, I felt a little something was missing from the flavor. I think the next time, I will double the oregano. I'll put 1/2 tsp in the flour mixture and another 1/2 tsp in the sauce. Here's what I did: I removed as much fat from the chicken breast as possible and beat it flat with my rolling pin (that's all I had to beat it with- worked like a charm). Added Durkees chicken season to the flour mixture with the pepper, salt, and oregano. Browned the chicken in 4tbsp of olive oil, but only 2 tbsp of butter. I did not have to add any more oil to the recipe as others have stated. This was plenty. I removed the chicken while it was still pink in the middle and sauteed some chopped onions along with about 2 cups of baby bella mrooms in the same oil. When nearly all of the liquid was gone from the pan, I deglazed the pan with 3/4 cup of Marsala cooking wine. Did not use any sherry. I added one can of Campbell's cream of chic w/ herbs and this thickened the sauce nicely. Did not have to add any cornstarch or flour. I also added 2tsp of heavy whipping cream. Last, I added the chicken back in and let it simmer in the sauce for about 7 minutes, then turned the chicken and let it simmer an add'l 7 min. The chicken was tender and delicious. As I stated earlier, I think adding 1/2 tsp of oregano to the sauce will make it perfect next time. Or a better marsala. This recipe is definitely worth a try.
Review:
Rating:
5

Oh wow! This was really easy to make and delicious. After reading the other reviews, I doubled the about of Marsala and mushrooms, added a splash of chicken stock, and used a cornstarch/water mixture to thicken the sauce. I bought the best Marsala wine I could find and added chopped parsley as a garnish. Instead of having pasta with it I went with olive oil/balsamic vinegar grilled zucchini strips.

text:
My family loved this recipe as written!!!  I only made two changes, I added into the flour/spice mixture, 1 packet of granulated chicken bouillon, which added more flavor than regular salt would have. We love mushrooms so I doubled the amount. As for prep,  I took another reviewers advice to put the flour/spice mixture in a plastic sandwich  bag, then added each piece of chicken then shook the bag to coat chicken. Made for a quick and easy clean up. Will definitely add to my dinner rotation!! Thanks for sharing!

It was very easy to make and delicious. My guests raved over it. I used regular dry sherry instead of cooking sherry to cut down on salt. I served with spaghetti and ladled the sauce and mushrooms over that, and a side of steamed vegetables.

text:
This was okay, but not exceptional. The biggest problem was that there wasn't much complexity of flavor in the recipe - almost all I could taste in the final recipe was the sherry and marsala. I like *some* marsala flavor, but that's not *all* I want to taste. I ended up adding a couple generous glugs of half & half to mellow it out a bit, but the marsala was still pretty overwhelming, so I added some cornstarch, which helped thicken it and mellow it a bit more. I'll keep looking for a better recipe.

This recipe was great!  I did change a few things like using Italian seasoned bread crumbs with shredded parmesean cheese instead of the flour mixture. region:

country:
None
text:
I must not be a Marsala fan as I didn't care much for the sauce. The chicken is good, my pan was too small so I did the sauce separately. I sauteed minced garlic and a shallot with the mushrooms (increased those two cups), added the wine and let simmer. Tried it and the Marsala was overwhelming (at least to me). Decided to doctor it with salt, pepper, garlic powder, Worcestershire sauce, milk and grainy Dijon mustard. End result was quite tasty. Maybe I should have followed the recipe a little better, but at least I found it edible with my changes. I give it 3 stars, the fiance 4. Probably won't make this again.

text:
This was awesome.  I was looking for something simple and easy to put together with ingredients that I already had on hand.  I only had chicken tenderloins so I used those.  I added Italian bread crumbs to the flour mixture along with some crushed red pepper.  I like a little kick :)  I also used white wine with the marsala wine because I didn't have any sherry.  I took the advice of some reviewers and thickened the sauce with cornstarch.  I would have used heavy whipping cream if I had it.  That would have been amazing, I'm sure.  I served it with spaghetti flavored with butter, thyme, salt and pepper.

So quick and easy to make.  Added to our regular rotation.  I used two cups of sliced mushrooms, a little bit of onion we had left in the fridge, double the marsala wine and sherry.  I don't add salt to the flour mixture.  Talking to my mom, found out she always made it with nutmeg instead of oregano and added some beef broth and flour and boiled it down until it was nice and thick.

text:
I made this tonight for our weekly family dinners with my hubby's parents and everyone really liked it. Even my kids and 1 yr. old neice ate it and cleaned their plates. I was a little wary of cooking this cause my hubby's fam. is usally really picky, but even dad went back for seconds. I did follow people's advice and added garlic to the chicken. I also did not use sherry, cut down the wine just a little and replaced both with chicken stock and added cream. i used a bit of the seasoned flour to thicken, instead of plain or cornstarch. we ate the chicken and doubled sauce with fettucini noodles. It was fantastic, tasted just like it would eating out.

160
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614256.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'm a big fan of chicken marsala and this recipe was wonderful and so quick/easy!  I like lots of sauce so I followed some other reviewer's advice and doubled the marsala wine and sherry.  I also added an entire pkg of 10 oz. sliced mushrooms.  (looks like a lot but they cook down significantly)  Lastly, after the chicken was finished simmering I removed and set aside, and added a mixture of 1Tbs corn starch and 1 Tbs water (slurry) along with a splash of heavy whipping cream to the sauce and mushrooms left in the skillet.  I whisked until thickened and then served the chicken and sauce over angel hair pasta.  Awesome!!!

text:
Believe it or not- this is my 9 year olds favorite dish! He likes this with white rice. The only changes I make are soaking the meat in buttermilk & seasonings (usually salt & pepper) just for the extra punch. *note for those that don't cook with wine often, NEVER cook with a wine you don't drink! I'm not huge on most wines- however, I grab ones specifically for cooking based on their stand alone taste. (sampling events are great for this) Also, the alcohol cooks off for those worried!

Display Name:
grade8teacher

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/201444.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a delicious recipe that I only slightly modified. I added minced garlic and 1/2 cup red onions. To the flour mixture I also added a dash of salt and some Mrs. Dash seasoning. I put the flour mixture and the chicken in a rectangular plastic container and shook them together. I also added an extra 1/2 cup of Marsala wine and cut the butter to about 1 1/2 tablespoon without hurting the flavor. My husband said this was the best Chicken Marsala he had ever had. I served this with skin-on garlic mashed potatoes and broccoli. It is a keeper!

This dish is awesome! The only thing I did different was use all marsala wine because I did not have cooking sherry and it was great! I served it over spagetti and with a green vegetable.   I made this because I had to cook the chicken that was in the fridge or it will spoil. I was hungry, my fiance was not. When it was all ready I made a plate for myself and fed a bite to him while he was in the middle of a sentence. Well he lost his thought and had to stop and go make a plate for himslef too. So yummy and so quick to make!

userID:
2738930
Display Name:
Robin Beaver
isPro:
False
followersCount:
14
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
83
favoritesCount:
933
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6542832.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
After making this and re-reading the recipe, I'm confused about one point. The description of this recipe states, “Herbed chicken in a sweet Marsala and mushroom sauce ..." The recipe list, however, doesn't call for either sweet or dry Marsala.  I used dry, because that's what I have in the house. It was definitely not a sweet Marsala sauce the way I cooked it, but we thought it was an excellent dish. I used 2.5 lbs. of chicken (5 breasts) and cooked it in two batches. Tripled the flour mixture. Kept the cooked chicken aside while I sauteed the vegetables, which consisted of extra mushroom (a must), to which I added shallots and fresh garlic. Added the chicken back in to the mushroom mixture with the Marsala. I'm not sure why this recipe calls for "cooking" sherry along with the Marsala.  Perhaps it's to tone down the sweetness if you're using sweet Marsala. Nevertheless, use a good-quality dry sherry, if you use it at all.  I added at least a cup of the Marsala and sherry, because I wanted more sauce, but next time I'll skip the sherry and add a bit of chicken broth rather than extra wine.  At the very end, I added some FF half and half, more cracked pepper and salt. Served over angel hair pasta with a side of crisp, French-style green beans. Delish!  P.S.  If anyone can figure out the sweet vs. dry Marsala for this recipe, please advise.
Review:
Rating:
4

text:
Fantastic! Better than what some resteraunts have tried to pass off as chicken marsala.  I have mad this recipe twice now. First as written and second with additions. My family and I really like th taste the spices so we upped the oregano to 1 tsp and added 1/2 tsp of dried thyme to the flour. Then before adding the mushrooms I addeed 1 clove of garlic. Once the wine and sherry and wine were added I let them cook a minute to blend the flavors. Finally I too a 1/2 cup chicken stock with about 2/3 of a tablespoon measure mixed in and added to the sauce. It thinckened nicely, and it was all fantastic over noodles.

text:
The whole family loves this recipe. After I've used the flour mixture on the chicken, I add the mushrooms to the little bit that's left in the dish, stir to coat them, and then scrape it all into the pan when it's time to add it. I think it makes the "gravy" a little thicker. Also I only use 3TBS of the butter/olive oil.

text:
I used several tips from Previous reviewers as well.  I stuck to using the two wines but after browning the chicken I removed it and sauted the mushrooms (Double the batch) in the oil/butter the chicken had just fried in.  Then poured in double the amount of wine and made a slurry of the left over seasoned flour and canned chicken broth.  Once mostly thickened I poured in about 1 cup of HEAVY CREAM!  Turned the fire way down and stired it and put the chicken back in to simmer for the 10 minutes. All I can say is YUMM YUUMMMM!!!

userID:
725087
Display Name:
SWIMYFISH
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
37
favoritesCount:
379
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/484250.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent with a few modifications.

Added garlic powder (1/2 tblspn) to flour mixture. Only used 1/2 amount of butter and NO OIL to cook chicken. After I cooked chicken on both sides, I removed from pan like other reviewers suggested. I deglazed the pan with marsala wine and added the mushrooms and some red wine (1/4c) b/c I did not have any sherry. Let them cook for about 7 minutes then added  a small mix of flour and red wine to the pan to help thinken the sauce. After it thickened, I removed the mushroom mixture and placed the chicken back in the pan and added some marsala wine to cook the chciken a few more minutes. I served the marsala sauce on top of the chicken and mashed potatoes - it was excellent!

Really really good. Here are my little tweaks/suggestions:
I cut the chicken breasts into about six pieces each before pounding them and also make sure and trim the fat.  After removing the chicken from the skillet, I deglazed it with about 1/4 cup marsala and dash of sherry.  After it reduced by about 1/2 I added about 1/8 a cup of cream and stirred/cooked for about 1 minute more. Poured it over the top of the chicken. DELICIOUS!!!!

text:
This was a nice easy recipe that produced a delicious meal.  I took the advice of others and was glad I did otherwise I don't think the chicken would have had as much flavor - added 1 t. garlic powder, 1/2 t. basil and 1/2 t. Mrs. Dash garlic seasoning blend to flour mixture - used plastic bag to coat chicken.  I used 3/4 of the amount of butter and olive oil and doubled the sauce  - it was just enough, but next time I would probably triple it.  It definitely needed thickening and I removed the chicken/mushrooms after simmering, placed them covered in the oven to keep warm and thickened the sauce with 1/2 cup of half and half and 1 T. of corn starch.  I served it over thin spaghetti.  It was delicious and everyone really liked it.  I would definitely make it again.
